full_text: No. 896. THE DAILY RECORD, WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1909. □I DRESDEN Prince Ernst of Sachsen-Weimar-Eisenach died at noon yesterday in the sanatorium of Neuwittelsbach, near Munich. Many friends in Dresden will hear with regret of the death on Sunday last of the Rev. Professor D. W. Simon, who for some time past has been resident in this city. Dr. Simon held the rank of Emeritus Principal of the Yorkshire United Indepen dent College, Bradford, since his resignation of the active duties of Principal and Professor of Systematic Theology in 1907. In his work of Theological Lec turer, Dr. Simon was especially well fitted by his training first at the Lancashire Independent College, Manchester, and later at the University of Halle, where he gained the degree of Doctor of Philosophy. In recognition of his eminent scholarship the Ho norary Degree of Doctor of Divinity was also con ferred upon him by the University of Edinburgh. He was a man of massive learning and was distin guished by his competence as a German scholar, a language which was to him interchangeable with his mother tongue. After his college career termi nated he spent some years in Berlin, where he acted as Director of the British and Foreign Bible Society and was associated with others in the founding of the cabmens’ mission, and in the establishment and extension of German Sunday schools. He was al lied with the Fatherland by marriage, his wife being a direct descendant of the old German family of Chemnitz, one of whom was the famous theologian Martin Chemnitz (died 1586), who was Superinten dent of the chief church in Braunschweig, where his memorial tablet bears the inscription “No Chemnitz, no Luther,” the significance of which is that without Martin Chemnitz the Reformation would have come to naught. With this adequate equipment Dr. Simon was called to be Professor and Principal at the Springhill Theological College, Birmingham. Previ ous to the removal of this foundation to Mansfield College, Oxford, he had undertaken the Principalship of the Edinburgh Theological Hall, from which po sition he became Principal of the Yorkshire United College. Dr. Simon’s knowledge of German literature, par ticularly in the realms of philosophy and theology, was unsurpassed by any British scholar, and no one was better equipped for the task, or more acute, in the prosecution of the duty, of investigating the extremer conclusions of German professors and writers. While himself fully abreast of modern re search and at all times ready to receive and to assi milate well-founded conclusions of theological science, he yet was able to do much to guide the thought of the time along safer and saner paths. As a writer he is well known, his principal works being: “The Redemption of Man,” “The Bible an outgrowth of . Theocratic Literature,” “Bible Problems,” and “Twice Born”—a volume of pulpit discourses. He was also in much demand as a translator of German theolo gians, among his wiork in this being: Stahlin’s cri tique of Kant, Lotze, and Ritschl, and the two vo lumes of Domer’s “Person of Christ,” one of which he translated and to both of which he contributed valuable critical notes. He wrote the article on Justi fication in Hasting’s Bible Dictionary and was a frequent contributor to English and American theolo gical journals. During his comparatively brief stay in Dresden he was a worshipper at the Scots Church, and ren dered invaluable service to the congregation by undertaking its pulpit duties for some months dur ing the recent interregnum. Jan Kubfelik appeared on Monday evening, after two years’ absence, to add fresh fuel to the fire of the re putation he'enjoys among his Dresden admirers. He has done so; his pale face surrounded by splendid black hair contributing, perhaps, no less to his success than his brilliant violin-playing. He is still what he was—the “wonder-man,” with the sweet tone and the even but by no means unique execution; the “Ratcatcher” who in fatuates female hearts by his sweet singing. Regarded from a musical point of view, he has not improved at all, has not become deeper. He plays—no matter what. It is always the charming tone and the smooth execution, always Herr Kubelik, that cajoles the public. He knows beforehand how to catch his audience. If one observes him closely, one knows his thoughts. His countenance betrays him: “Pay attention! now you will again be carried away.” And he is right in his reckoning; the audience is carried away, and applauds rapturously. Herr Kubelik played it as - he plays everything, with the sweet tone and the smooth execution,—played it as he played Lalo’s Spanish Rhapsody. It is indeed a matter of indifference what Herr Kubelik plays. His success is assured; the audience is jubilant. The longer Herr Kubelik played, the more the audience cheered on Monday; and when the Paganini Etudes and Hubay’s “Scene de la Czarda” had been heard, the applause became so frantic that the little pale Bohemian with the dark curly hair might have imagined himself in America, where skilful “reclame” can produce more enthusiasm than in prosaic Germany. It if. to be regretted that Herr Kubelik played without an orchestra, though with the clever pianoforte accompaniments of Herr Schwab. Thus the Concertos of Sinding and Lalo were heard in a mutilated form. But that is a matter of in difference. The chief thing remained: Herr Kubelik played. —One great merit the concert had; it made us acquainted with an unusually talented pianoforte-player, Herr Ludwig Raab, hitherto quite a stranger to Dresden. True, it was only frothy “must” that the young artist gave us; but it promised in course of time to become noble, golden wine, that will strengthen and elevate when once it is refined. The audience overwhelmed Herr Raab, too, with applause. 1 M. N. % The Leipzig police made a capture early yesterday morning under somewhat exciting circumstances. A workman named Heil, who was wanted on a charge of burglary, was traced to a house in the suburb of Kleinzschocher, in which neighbourhood he had been living by poaching. On seeing the police enter the house, Heil jumped out of a window, and attempted to escape, firing a revolver at the policeman nearest to him. He was about to fire again, when he fell, severely wounded by a shot from 1 a second policeman. He was secured and taken to hospital. -t— The guards in the city today are furnished by the 1st Grenadier regiment No. 100, whose band plays about 12.30 p.m. at the Schloss Platz. Herr Paul Wiecke will read a selection of Goethe’s poems. DRESDEN CURRENT ENTERTAINMENTS. Royal Opera House. Tonight, beginning at 7.30, ending 9.45 Die drei Pintos. Comic opera in three acts. Music by C. M. v. Weber. Cast: Don Pantaleone, Roiz de Pacheco 1 Madrid (Herr Nebuschka. Don Gomez, Freiros J Nobles {Herr Grosch. Clarissa, Don Pantaleone’s daughter . . . Fraul. Seebe. Laura, Clarissa’s maid Frau Wedekind. Don Gaston Viratos, formerly student at Salamanca Herr Soot. Don Pinto de Fonseca, a young land noble from Castrilla Herr Foerster. The landlord of the inn at Penaranda . . Herr Puttlitz. Inez, his daughter Frau Nast. Ambrosio, Don Gaston’s servant Herr Trede. A student Herr Loschcke. Jhe House Steward of Pantaleone .... Herr Bussel. PLOT. Don Gaston Viratos, a student, is discovered taking leave of his comrades. His money is rapidly vanishing while he is busily engaged in a flirtation with the daughter of his host, Inez, being assisted by his servant Ambrosio. Enters upon the scene Don Pinto de Fonseca, whose exceeding cor pulence arouses general amusement. He imparts to Gaston that he has come to marry a rich and noble lady, Donna Clarissa de Pacheco, whose hand has been promised him by the girl’s father out of gratitude for a service rendered by the suitor’s father. He is undecided how to proceed in the delicate matter of courtship, and Gaston thereupon offers to be his mentor. Subsequently they feast together, Don Pinto becoming the worse for wine. While his companion is lying in a stupor, Gaston steals his letter of recommendation to Donna Clarissa, and departs. The second act shows us the scene in Don Pantaleone’s ancestral hall, where he makes announcement of his daughter’s impending marriage. The lady, however, is enamoured of Don Gomez Freiros. a noble young knight, and is in despair at the prospect of a match with Pinto. Her maid Laura promises to discover a way out of the dilemma. In the third act the hail is decorated for the approaching nuptials. The servants all leave upon Don Pinto’s arrival being proclaimed, but Clarissa’s maid. Laura, hides. Gaston (the pretended suitor) now arrives and meets Don Gomez, who arouses the pretender’s sympathy by revealing his love for Clarissa. A plot is quickly arranged. Don Gomez assumes the role of Pinto, is furnished with the re commendatory letter, and introduced as the prospective bridegroom. The father is favourably impressed by his bearing, and gives consent to the union. All is thus going well when the unexpected arrival of the real Don Pinto complicates matters. His absurd antics arouse the belief that he is mad, but seeing Gaston among the guests he accuses him of treachery. The student threatens Pinto with a sword, whereupon the unhappy suitor, crying for mercy, is bundled out neck and crop. At this juncture Gaston reveals the plot. There is a general uproar; but Clarissa’s father is made to see the contrast between Pinto and Gomez, and finally, under the influence of his daughter’s pleadings, gives the couple his benediction. Gaston receives the grateful acknowledgements of Gomez for the part he has played in winning him a lovely bride. Composer: Carl Maria von Weber, born 1786, died 1826. Thursday night . . . ANTI-ASIATIC LEGISLATION. Sacramento, January 19. In compliance with a request telegraphed to him by President Roosevelt, Governor Gillette has consented that the further parliamentary proceedings in the matter of the anti-Japanese law passed by the Californian House of Representatives shall be postponed. President Roosevelt, in the telegram referred to, expressed his great anxiety lest the passing of the law should do incalculable injury, not only to California but to the whole Union. (With reference to this despatch see telegram on page 1.) GREAT FIRE IN MESSINA. Messina, January 19. A great fire broke out last night among the ruins along the sea front and, fanned by a strong wind, burnt furiously. Soldiers and sailors did all they could to ex tinguish the flames, but were obliged at last to confine their efforts to isolating the fire. Rome, January 19. A special edition of the Giornale d’Italia says that the fire in Messina broke out in the Pennizi Palace, perhaps the only one whose outer walls had remained standing after the earthquake. The Duke of Genoa was present during the attempts to extinguish the flames. It is be lieved that the fire had been smouldering unobserved for days, and that its outbreak was due to the strong wind. Reports from the storm centre in the Near East which have lately come to hand are distinctly of a more favourable tone. A week or so ago the situa tion bid fair to increase in tensity, and no small amount of bellicose talk was heard from both Vienna and Belgrade. Then came the speech of the Servian Premier, M. Milovanovitch, mistranslations of which duly reached the Ballplatz and were construed in to a definite menace against Austria. So deep an impression did this speech make, indeed, that M. Milovanovitch was quickly called to account. His sub sequent explanation appears to have been decidedly satisfactory to the Austrian Government, and it is now to be hoped that hotheads on both sides will endeavour to restrain their fiery utterances which add very greatly to the difficulties of amicably solv ing the tangled problem of ‘‘who's wfi'o” in the Balkans. It is all very well for Austrian politicians to lecture the Servian press on its agitative pro pensities. These gentlemen, however, would do well to set their own printing house in order if one of their journals, the Montags-Zeitung, may be con sidered representative. This organ, with unexampled bad taste, actually invited Italy to take notice of the fact that Austria had not profited by the disorder caused by the earthquake catastrophe to invade Italian territory. This ignoble attitude on the part of the Austrian press is not calculated to weld closer Aus trian and Italian sympathies. Turning towards Con stantinople, the outlook is very much brighter. The reopening of negotiations between Vienna and the Yildiz Kiosk, provided a conciliatory spirit s ex hibited by the parties concerned, should go far to wards assuaging the fears formerly entertained of an open rupture. Austria’s olfer to pay compensa tion for the Turkish State property iq the annexed provinces is an indisputable guarantee of her good faith. It is a pity that this proposition was not put forward long ago, in which case much needless alarm would have been spared. There is, of course, another side to the matter. It 4 is quite on the cards that the present dispute will be provisionally settled without further delay; that Turkey will consent to officially acknowledge the action of Austria-Hungary, and put on the best face she can; that the Slav States now so vociferously clamouring against the Habsburg policy will subside into silence. But for how long? The former status quo in the Balkans has been irreparably upset. It remains to be seen whether it has been changed permanently for the better. MR. TAFTS PANAMA TRIP. New York, January 10. Mr. Taft, the President-Elect, is still in Georgia, nominally recruiting his health after the prolonged strain of the elections, and preparing for his forth coming visit to the Isthmus of Panama. There is nothing of the invalid about him, however, for he plays golf almost every day, and receives politicians daily, in connection with the formation of his first Administration, and the formulation of his policy. He will start for the Isthmus some time this week. DRESDEN CHINA f-p. :: Own workmanship :: Lowest prices : Ujl :: Retail Export Wholesale :• A. E. Mr. Cortelyou, Secretary of the Treasury, proposes on the 23rd of January to call in 15 million dollars, and on the 10th of February 10 million dollars of State funds from the National Banks. The Secretary r ^ Treasur y * s desirous that the commencement of Mr. Taft’s administration will find ample gold reserves in the United States Treasury. MR. ROOSEVELT’S CHARGES. THE SECRET SERVICE AFFAIR. Washington, January 10. President Roosevelt has published details of the investigation conducted by Post Office inspectors and Secret Service agents into Senator Tillman’s connection with an alleged “land grab” in Oregon, as embodied in the letter sent by the President to Senator Hale in obedience to the Senate’s re quest for information regarding the uses made of the Secret Service. The President undertakes to show that Mr. Tillman used his influence as a Senator in an effort to force the Government to compel the Railroad Corporation to relinquish its control of the land grants from .the United States in order that he, his family, and secretary might profit by the purchase of land, and .that the Senator used the granting privilege on nurperous occasions in the conduct of his private business. The Pre sident’s communication to Senator Hale extends to 3,000 words, and appended to it are copies of letters from Senator Tillman, in which he expresses a desire to secure several quarter-sections of Oregon land, and also reports by inspectors who investigated the affairs of the land company with which Senator Tillman was in communication. It appears that the investigation of the affairs of the land company which led to the discovery of Senator Tillman’s letters was made on Mr. Tillman’s own suggestion. Senator Tillman promises to reply to the President’s charges in the Senate on Monday. Washington, January 10. Senator Hale has called a sub-commission of the Senate, consisting of three members, in order to in vestigate the insinuations with regard to the relations between Representatives and the Secret Service con tained in Mr. Roosevelt’s Message to Congress. Washington, January 10. In consequence of the excitement produced by the remarks on the subject of the secret police service made by President Roosevelt in his message to Con gress, Senator Depew has given notice that Con gress will from this time forth enquire whether the persons nominated by the President for official posts are suitable. This course of action is regarded as an effective weapon against President Roosevelt. THE EARTHQUAKE DISASTER. REMARKABLE RESCUE REPORTS. ALIVE AFTER FOURTEEN DAYS. Messina, January 10. About noon today the rescuers succeeded in ex tricating from the ruins a 43-year-old man, who had been pinned beneath the debris of his house for fourteen days. Under the circumstances, he was in remarkably good health. During his incarcera tion he had perforce to witness the slow death of his wife and four children. For the whole time he had of course been without provisions or water. Since yesterday inclement weather has prevailed here ; during the foregoing night a heavy storm broke! Several fresh shocks have also been experienced. Naples, January 10. I he American battleship “Connecticut” arrived here today. The battleships “Vermont,” “Kansas,” and “Minnesota” are expected shortly. Rome, January 10. General Mazza telegraphs from Messina to the Premier as follows: “On the 7th inst. six survivors were rescued from the ruins. Gold and notes to the amount of five million lire have been recovered and sent to Catania under military escort. Private persons have now received permission to save what they can of their household goods under the super vision of troops. In the town and vicinity order prevails, and only a few arrests have been made in consequence of looting. The rescue work con tinues without intermission. Every night patrols go round for the purpose of hearing cries for help which may proceed from under the ruins. The hygienic conditions are favourable. Fresh earthquake shocks caused a violent agitation of the sea today. Huge waves broke along the shore and swept away one of the wharves on which were piles of flour sacks, a wagon and horse, and three railway trucks loaded with provisions.” ^ . Bremen, January 10. Owing to reports received here by the North Ger man Lloyd Company from their officials, and from the maritime authorities at Naples, to the effect that no danger attends the passage of ships through the Straits of Messina by day, the Company has cancelled its orders issued directly after the earth quake, according to which the vessels of its Mediter ranean lines were to avoid the Straits and proceed along the west coast of Sicily. This postponement is owing to several of the Deputies and Ministers havi ”& gone to the earthquake territory to prepare official reports. The aqueduct at Messina is again in working order. An analysis of the water shows it to be absolutely pure. ..... ' Milan, January 10. Violent snowstorms are reported from all parts of central Italy. Telegraphic and telephonic com munication between Milan and Rome is interrupted. ... Messina, January 11. 1 he provisional municipal administration has now assumed the task of burying the victims of the cata strophe. The burial bureau is conducted by civi lians, under the supervision of two medical men. THE SECRET SERVICE AFFAIR. Washington, January 10. President Roosevelt has published details of the investigation conducted by Post Office inspectors and Secret Service agents into Senator Tillman’s connection with an alleged “land grab” in Oregon, as embodied in the letter sent by the President to Senator Hale in obedience to the Senate’s re quest for information regarding the uses made of the Secret Service. The President undertakes to show that Mr. Tillman used his influence as a Senator in an effort to force the Government to compel the Railroad Corporation to relinquish its control of the land grants from .the United States in order that he, his family, and secretary might profit by the purchase of land, and .that the Senator used the granting privilege on nurperous occasions in the conduct of his private business. The Pre sident’s communication to Senator Hale extends to 3,000 words, and appended to it are copies of letters from Senator Tillman, in which he expresses a desire to secure several quarter-sections of Oregon land, and also reports by inspectors who investigated the affairs of the land company with which Senator Tillman was in communication. Washington, January 10. In consequence of the excitement produced by the remarks on the subject of the secret police service made by President Roosevelt in his message to Con gress, Senator Depew has given notice that Con gress will from this time forth enquire whether the persons nominated by the President for official posts are suitable. This course of action is regarded as an effective weapon against President Roosevelt. THE EARTHQUAKE DISASTER. REMARKABLE RESCUE REPORTS. ALIVE AFTER FOURTEEN DAYS. Messina, January 10. About noon today the rescuers succeeded in ex tricating from the ruins a 43-year-old man, who had been pinned beneath the debris of his house for fourteen days. Under the circumstances, he was in remarkably good health. During his incarcera tion he had perforce to witness the slow death of his wife and four children. For the whole time he had of course been without provisions or water. Since yesterday inclement weather has prevailed here ; during the foregoing night a heavy storm broke! Several fresh shocks have also been experienced. Naples, January 10. I he American battleship “Connecticut” arrived here today. The battleships “Vermont,” “Kansas,” and “Minnesota” are expected shortly. Rome, January 10. General Mazza telegraphs from Messina to the Premier as follows: “On the 7th inst. six survivors were rescued from the ruins. Gold and notes to the amount of five million lire have been recovered and sent to Catania under military escort. Private persons have now received permission to save what they can of their household goods under the super vision of troops. In the town and vicinity order prevails, and only a few arrests have been made in consequence of looting. The rescue work con tinues without intermission. Every night patrols go round for the purpose of hearing cries for help which may proceed from under the ruins. The hygienic conditions are favourable. Fresh earthquake shocks caused a violent agitation of the sea today. Huge waves broke along the shore and swept away one of the wharves on which were piles of flour sacks, a wagon and horse, and three railway trucks loaded with provisions.” ^ . Bremen, January 10. Owing to reports received here by the North Ger man Lloyd Company from their officials, and from the maritime authorities at Naples, to the effect that no danger attends the passage of ships through the Straits of Messina by day, the Company has cancelled its orders issued directly after the earth quake, according to which the vessels of its Mediter ranean lines were to avoid the Straits and proceed along the west coast of Sicily. T , r ^ Rome, January 10. l he Chamber • of Deputies will not reassemble before February 16, instead of the date originally fixed, namely, February 3. This postponement is owing to several of the Deputies and Ministers havi ”& gone to the earthquake territory to prepare official reports. The aqueduct at Messina is again in working order. An analysis of the water shows it to be absolutely pure. ..... ' Milan, January 10. Violent snowstorms are reported from all parts of central Italy. Telegraphic and telephonic com munication between Milan and Rome is interrupted. ... Messina, January 11. 1 he provisional municipal administration has now assumed the task of burying the victims of the cata strophe. The burial bureau is conducted by civi lians, under the supervision of two medical men. Train communication has been re-established in all directions, but travellers are not allowed to enter Messina without a permit from the commandant. Yesterday a collection in aid of survivors was made among the soldiers comprising the garrison.

T- AMERICA AND GERMANY. A SENSATIONAL REPORT. ______ London, January *7. The Morning Post publishes a cablegram Trom its Washington correspondent to the following ef fect : “Germany is negotiating with the United States for a mutual agreement respecting patents. The United States have at present no law correspond ing to the law which prescibes the carrying out of patents by a German in Germany; but a Bill to supply that want has been laid before Congress. Germany has now offered not to bring her law into operation against the United States, provided that the United States, if a similar law should be there enacted, will refrain from putting it itn force against Germany.” The Morning Post is further informed that the German Ambassador has assured the State Depart ment that, if the above agreement is concluded, the German law will be applied with stringency against Great Britain; which would be equivalent to giving a preference to ‘the United States. (Wolff’s Telegraphic Bureau informs us that the German Ambassador in Washington has received no instructions to make such a statement to the United States Government. The last paragraph is charac terised as an invention.) SACRILEGIOUS BURGLARY. The Church at Baasen, in the Rhine Province, was broken into on Tuesday night by robbers, who carried off all the gold and siLver vessels and orna ments from the altar. The police have as yet no clue to the perpetrators. THE EARTHQUAKE DISASTER. OUTBREAK OF SMALLPOX. HARROWING NARRATIVES. Rome, January 7. At Palmi, the greater part of which was des troyed by the earthquake, smallpox has broken out. The bacteriological institute of Milan has sent lymph enough for 25,000 inoculations to the phy sicians at Palmi. A meeting of survivors was held on the ruins of Messina yesterday, which was attended by a Senator and several Deputies. The meeting passed a re solution advocating the rebuilding of Messina as an historical and national work, and expressing the belief that Pdi liaineni, in accordance with, tne wishes of the entire nation, .would take measures to secure Messina against a repetition of the disaster and to give the city a new lease of life. In the course oi an interview with a press re presentative, Signor Orlando, Minister of Justice, declared that Messina would rise again from its shes. The town should be rebuilt by private in itiative, and the Government would probably lend the money on very favourable terms. The Minister paid a warm tribute to the unselfish conduct of the soldiers, who, after a long sea voyage, insisted on being allowed to join in the work of rescue at once. Fatigue was forgotten as long as there was a chance of saving anybody. The King had given a splendid example of fearlessness and de votion, and continually passed under tottering walls, oblivious of the danger. The Queen had personally attended to the injured, and both she and the King assisted at operations. Signor Giolitti, the Premier, repeats that he will not have recourse to a loan to raise the funds necessary for the. organisation of relief works in Calabria and Sicily, arid will confine himself to setting aside a sum of 30,0,00,000 lire from the Budgetary surplus. This will be sufficient to meet the most pressing needs. The money that will afterwards be required will, according to the Corriere d’ltalia, be procured by means of an increase in the land and income taxes. Jt is expected that the requisite sum of 180,000,000 lire could be raised in two years in this way. ,The Corriere d’ltalia publishes a notice warn ing the public against individuals who are seeking to impose upon the charitably-disposed by cloth ing themselves in rags and representing themselves to be refugees from the earthquake region. Messina, January 6. The conflicting reports regarding the fate of the Rev. Charles Huleatt, the British Chaplain at Messina, are set at rest by the following circumstantial ac count:—On Friday afternoon, after long, cautious, and tiring work the house of Mr. Huleatt, the British chaplain, was discovered, or, to be more exact, the pile of ruins into wthich the house had been transformed, was found. The rescuing party, how ever, under Lieut. Bavin, of the cruiser “Minerva,” through heroic efforts succeeded in reaching a point Under the debris from which they heard groans proceeding, showing that one or more of the in mates was still living. This discovery infused fresh vigour into them,: but although the work was con tinued until late at night nobody was found, and the darkness made it necessary to suspend opera tions, for fear that the rescuers might complete what the earthquake had begun, and kilt the un fortunates who still had breath in their bodies. The work was resumed’ at daybreak on Saturday. - (Continued on psge 2.)

At Palmi, the greater part of which was des troyed by the earthquake, smallpox has broken out. The bacteriological institute of Milan has sent lymph enough for 25,000 inoculations to the phy sicians at Palmi. A meeting of survivors was held on the ruins of Messina yesterday, which was attended by a Senator and several Deputies. The meeting passed a re solution advocating the rebuilding of Messina as an historical and national work, and expressing the belief that Pdi liaineni, in accordance with, tne wishes of the entire nation, .would take measures to secure Messina against a repetition of the disaster and to give the city a new lease of life. In the course oi an interview with a press re presentative, Signor Orlando, Minister of Justice, declared that Messina would rise again from its shes. The town should be rebuilt by private in itiative, and the Government would probably lend the money on very favourable terms. The Minister paid a warm tribute to the unselfish conduct of the soldiers, who, after a long sea voyage, insisted on being allowed to join in the work of rescue at once. Fatigue was forgotten as long as there was a chance of saving anybody. The King had given a splendid example of fearlessness and de votion, and continually passed under tottering walls, oblivious of the danger. The Queen had personally attended to the injured, and both she and the King assisted at operations. Signor Giolitti, the Premier, repeats that he will not have recourse to a loan to raise the funds necessary for the. organisation of relief works in Calabria and Sicily, arid will confine himself to setting aside a sum of 30,0,00,000 lire from the Budgetary surplus. This will be sufficient to meet the most pressing needs. The money that will afterwards be required will, according to the Corriere d’ltalia, be procured by means of an increase in the land and income taxes. Jt is expected that the requisite sum of 180,000,000 lire could be raised in two years in this way. ,The Corriere d’ltalia publishes a notice warn ing the public against individuals who are seeking to impose upon the charitably-disposed by cloth ing themselves in rags and representing themselves to be refugees from the earthquake region. Messina, January 6. The conflicting reports regarding the fate of the Rev. Charles Huleatt, the British Chaplain at Messina, are set at rest by the following circumstantial ac count:—On Friday afternoon, after long, cautious, and tiring work the house of Mr. Huleatt, the British chaplain, was discovered, or, to be more exact, the pile of ruins into wthich the house had been transformed, was found. The rescuing party, how ever, under Lieut. Bavin, of the cruiser “Minerva,” through heroic efforts succeeded in reaching a point Under the debris from which they heard groans proceeding, showing that one or more of the in mates was still living. This discovery infused fresh vigour into them,: but although the work was con tinued until late at night nobody was found, and the darkness made it necessary to suspend opera tions, for fear that the rescuers might complete what the earthquake had begun, and kilt the un fortunates who still had breath in their bodies. The work was resumed’ at daybreak on Saturday. - (Continued on psge 2.)

BERLIN We are requested by the American Embassy in Berlin to state that the American Ambassador ex pects to keep his usual office hours at the offices of the Embassy in Unter den Linden, where he will receive persons calling upon him on business. Any statement to the contrary is unauthorised and misleading. Mr. Andrew Carnegie has authorised the American Ambassador, Dr. Hill, to transmit to the Koch In stitute for Tuberculosis at Berlin his gift of 500,000 marks. Dr. Hill^on Wednesday deposited the mo ney in the name of Mr. Carnegie to the order of the Treasurer of the Robert Koch-Stiftung in the Konigliche Preussische Staatsbank. Dr. Hill also communicated to the President of the Koch Institute Mr. Carnegie’s cordial acknow ledgement of his election as Honorary Member, and his good wishes for all possible success in its bene ficent work. A magnificent laurel wreath bearing on heavy white satin the inscriptipn: “The American Asso ciation of Commerce and Trade in Berlin, To its Esteemed Director and Member, Herr Kommerzien- rat Ferdinand Hecht,” was to be seen in the rooms of the Association on Wednesday morning. It was the Association’s last tribute of appreciation to its late member. The funeral of Mr. Hecht, who was buried in the Weissensee cemetery, took place on Wednesday afternoon, and was attended by Secre tary Atwood on behalf of the Association. Mr. Alexander Konta, of New York, one of the proprietors of the New York Sun, left Berlin on Tuesday night after a week’s stay at the Hotel Adlon. After attending to business interests in Vienna and Constantinople he will go to Nice for a brief pleasure stay, returning to Berlin in three weeks’ time. New Year’s holidays, has been afflicted during the I the Annual Dinner of the American Association of past few days with a heavy cold, which compelled Commers and Trade on “The Geography of Com- him to postpone his departure for Paris and London. | meree.” y Mr. George Ade, America’s famous humorist and actor, was in Berlin for a few days this week, stopping at Hotel Adlon. He expected to leave on Thursday. Mr. Ade, who was accompanied by his friend Cap tain Vails, is said to have come up from Paris with the intention of having a talk with Mr. Alexander Konta. The Woman’s Union of the American Church held its regular monthly meeting on Tuesday afternoon at the home of the President, Dr. Alice Luce, Luit- pold Strasse 24. Rev. Dr. William Irving, of New York, delivered the address of the occasion. At the next regular meeting, the first Tuesday in February, Mrs. Harrison B. Riley, of Evanston, 111., will give an address on: “The Educational Power of the Drama.” Mr. Kenneth Bingham, the well-known New York baritone, sailed for America on Tuesday from Bremen, aboard the “Friedrich Wilhelm.” Mrs. Florence Jessie Hosel, whose remarkable needle-painting landscapes” have made her widely known both in Germany and England, entertained on Sunday evening,- January 3, at her picturesque apartment in the Colonie Grunewald, Schleinitz Strasse 6a. Covers were laid for forty. The delight ful hospitality of Mr. Hosel and his gifted wife made the evening a particularly enjoyable one. The ar tistic, musical, literary, and theatrical professions were represented among the guests. As they approached the point whence the groans proceeded, they under stood from the uniformity of the voice that the lamentation they heard came from one person only. The difficulties encountered were so great that the brave sailors often despaired of being* able to rescue the sufferers in time. At 8.14 in the evening an other distinct shock of earthquake rendered the situation graver, and the work still more danger ous, for the tottering walls around threatened mo mentarily to collapse, burying together victims and rescuers. But not one of the sailors thought of abandoning the task. Their persistence was partly rewarded ten minutes later, when Mr. Huleatt and were found in bed, crushed, but recog nisable, death having been instantaneous. It was a heart-breaking sight. The concert will be followed by a reception. Ad mission for members and non-members, 1 mark. With a view to replenishing its finances, the Ame rican Woman’s Club has also arranged a benefit Musicale to take place shortly, at which Mr. Putnam Griswold, of the Berlin Royal Opera, has agreed to furnish the programme. The Club held its annual general meeting for the election of officers and committees on Wednesday. Princess Victoria Louisa, who will next autumn celebrate her sixteenth birthday, made her debut in what the Germans call the “Grosse Welt” on Saturday last, when a dance was given at the Neues Palais in Potsdam. The princess herself opened the dancing festivities, this being her first appearance in society. The Bulletin says:—“For the past fortnight no express steamer has left a German port for New York, nor has the service from the United States to German ports been much better. The next Ger man Lloyd express vessel does not leave Bremen until January 19. This insufficient service is great ly embarrassing to business interests in both coun tries, and complaints are loud. Even if steamers do not get a full complement of passengers, ought German-American commercial interests to be so trammelled? Dr. Hill^on Wednesday deposited the mo ney in the name of Mr. Carnegie to the order of the Treasurer of the Robert Koch-Stiftung in the Konigliche Preussische Staatsbank. Dr. Hill also communicated to the President of the Koch Institute Mr. Carnegie’s cordial acknow ledgement of his election as Honorary Member, and his good wishes for all possible success in its bene ficent work. A magnificent laurel wreath bearing on heavy white satin the inscriptipn: “The American Asso ciation of Commerce and Trade in Berlin, To its Esteemed Director and Member, Herr Kommerzien- rat Ferdinand Hecht,” was to be seen in the rooms of the Association on Wednesday morning. It was the Association’s last tribute of appreciation to its late member. The funeral of Mr. Hecht, who was buried in the Weissensee cemetery, took place on Wednesday afternoon, and was attended by Secre tary Atwood on behalf of the Association. Mr. Alexander Konta, of New York, one of the proprietors of the New York Sun, left Berlin on Tuesday night after a week’s stay at the Hotel Adlon. After attending to business interests in Vienna and Constantinople he will go to Nice for a brief pleasure stay, returning to Berlin in three weeks’ time. full_text: No. 893. THE DAILY RECORD. SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1909. El We would again draw attention to the circum stance that the entire amount of the offertories col lected at the English Church of All Saints’ in Dres den tomorrow (Sunday) will be donated to the Lord Mayor’s (London) Fund in aid of sufferers from the terrible earthquake disaster in Sicily and Calabria. The twenty-fourth annual conference of the In corporated Society of Musicians was celebrated in London on Decembei 31 last by a grand orches tral concert in Queen’s Hall. One of the numbers on the programme is of particular interest to Dres den readers, having been written by a composer who is a well-known figure among the Anglo-Ame rican colony of this city. We refer to Mr. J. C. Ames, whose symphonic poem, “Sir Galahad,” was performed at the concert referred to above. Com menting upon this work, the London Standard writes: “From technical and constructive points of view ‘Sir Galahad’ was, perhaps, the most success ful work of the evening, the breadth and freedom of orchestration and the broad and melodious ‘Sir Galahad’ theme, which is finally worked up to a good climax, being most effective” Herr Alfred Sittard, the gifted Dresden organist, gave on Thursday evening, before a crowded au dience in the Kreuzkirche, the first of his organ recitals this year. His programme contained “Cho rale Preludes” only; the peculiar form in which German Protestant music has poured forth its poetry. The fact that Herr Sittard, in beginning with Bach and ending with Max Reger, gave a survey of the historical development of this form, lent special value and interest to the occasion. In Bach’s choral pre ludes, the poetical meaning of the text of the hymn is simply held amid the majestic splendour and mas sive grandeur of the musical structure. The melody of the Chorale is “sung” in one or other of the voice parts and treated contrapuntally, or it serves as the theme of a magnificent fugue. With Max Reger, whose famous arrangement of the Chorale “Wie schon leuchtet uns der Morgenstern” Herr Sittard played at the end of his programme, these choral preludes become organ symphonies, the different divisions of which draw their musical in spiration from the separate verses of the hymn-text. Between the Bach and Max Reger works Herr Sittard introduced the choral preludes of Brahms, op. 122, which only became known after the composer’s death; refined, fanciful compositions, full of tender melancholy and aptly bridging the gap between Bach and Reger. Herr Sittard overcame all technical dif ficulties, and they were sometimes very great, with easy grace. The absolute clearness of his phrasing and his admirable feeling for fine tone-blends were a constant source of enjoyment, and the unaffected simplicity of his style was throughout worthy of his great task. The performance was one that exalted the hearts of all who heard it; and it had the spe cial merit of being the best and quickest means of expanding and strengthening the understanding for organ works, which are far too little appre ciated. M. N. 1 Frau Meta Foerster-Bresson, the wife of the bass singer at the Royal opera, gave a concert at the Kiinstlerhaus on Thursday evening. Some years since, when this lady was studying the pianoforte under James Kwast at Frankfort on Main, she was con sidered to possess great talent which justified high hopes for her future success. Unquestionably, Frau Foerster does possess musical talent, but not pianis- tic talent. Her playing is too indistinct, inaccurate, and unequal. Her scales are quite uneven, her shakes confused, and her chords and octaves very uncer tain. All these defects Frau Foerster seeks to veil by abundant use of the pedal, and so makes her whole playing still more indistinct. That is a great pity, as she has good ideas of howi to study her composers and how to interpret them. That she showed with Brahms, whose B-minor Rhapsodie suited her particularly well. That the full effect of her intentions was not obtained, was due to in sufficient means. With Reger it was still worse. It is worthy of recognition that Frau Foerster placed the great Bach Variations with the pompous final Fugue on her programme, and that she played it with such sureness of memory. But this work requires different and grander treatment; not with the excess of motherly fervour that Frau Foerster felt for it. With Chopin she had better fortune; DRESDEN I Concert Agency H. N. 1 The guards in the city today are furnished by the Schiitzen regiment No. 108, whose band plays about 12.30 p.m. at the Schloss Platz. NEW BOOKS RECEIVED. * Mr. H. G. Wells made his first reputation as the author of brilliant scientific romances, after the man ner of Jules Verne. One early story, however, The Wheels of Chance, showed him as a subtle and sym pathetic student of the much-abused lower middle class. In Kipps he raises a member of this class to the level of the heroic. It is a story of a boy who becomes an assistant in a draper’s shop. The first part tells of his shop life, with all its dreari ness of outlook. Then by an extraordinary chance he falls heir to a fortune, and proceeds to train himself to be a member of the leisured class. How he loses his first fortune and finds a second, marries his first love and returns to the sober ideas of his youth, is all brilliantly and dramatically told in Mr. Wells’s story. It is a new type of art, for he uses none of the stage figures of ordinary fic tion. None the less it is pure romance, full of hu mour, pathos, and a wise philosophy. No more ori ginal and delightful book has been published in our time. No one who casually glances through the work of Lucas Malet will deny her more than ordinary literary merit' of the exotic type, coupled with a genius for originality which is sadly lacking now adays. This gifted authoress is well versed in the arts of her profession, in spite of the veiled super ficiality which characterises the narratives from her pen. Her studies of human nature are more dilettante than profound, and she is not free from a predilec tion for the suggestive. The Gate less Barrier, how ever, may be recommended as a distinctly clever and entertaining novel. As an exponent of modern English society Mr. E. F. Benson has made a brilliant name for him self. He is vigorous and yet discreet, just but sym pathetic, and he manfully resists the temptation to too closely create morbid “problems,” so frequently to be met with in latter-day fiction. The Climber is well up to the high standard which Mr. Benson has himself taught us to expect. It compares very favourably with earlier work from the same source. m * Kipps, by H. G. Wells. El We would again draw attention to the circum stance that the entire amount of the offertories col lected at the English Church of All Saints’ in Dres den tomorrow (Sunday) will be donated to the Lord Mayor’s (London) Fund in aid of sufferers from the terrible earthquake disaster in Sicily and Calabria. The twenty-fourth annual conference of the In corporated Society of Musicians was celebrated in London on Decembei 31 last by a grand orches tral concert in Queen’s Hall. One of the numbers on the programme is of particular interest to Dres den readers, having been written by a composer who is a well-known figure among the Anglo-Ame rican colony of this city. We refer to Mr. J. C. Ames, whose symphonic poem, “Sir Galahad,” was performed at the concert referred to above. Com menting upon this work, the London Standard writes: “From technical and constructive points of view ‘Sir Galahad’ was, perhaps, the most success ful work of the evening, the breadth and freedom of orchestration and the broad and melodious ‘Sir Galahad’ theme, which is finally worked up to a good climax, being most effective” Herr Alfred Sittard, the gifted Dresden organist, gave on Thursday evening, before a crowded au dience in the Kreuzkirche, the first of his organ recitals this year. His programme contained “Cho rale Preludes” only; the peculiar form in which German Protestant music has poured forth its poetry. The fact that Herr Sittard, in beginning with Bach and ending with Max Reger, gave a survey of the historical development of this form, lent special value and interest to the occasion. In Bach’s choral pre ludes, the poetical meaning of the text of the hymn is simply held amid the majestic splendour and mas sive grandeur of the musical structure. The melody of the Chorale is “sung” in one or other of the voice parts and treated contrapuntally, or it serves as the theme of a magnificent fugue. With Max Reger, whose famous arrangement of the Chorale “Wie schon leuchtet uns der Morgenstern” Herr Sittard played at the end of his programme, these choral preludes become organ symphonies, the different divisions of which draw their musical in spiration from the separate verses of the hymn-text. full_text: 4 THE DAILY RECORD, SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1909. No. 893.* RECOLLECTIONS OF SAXONY. By Lady Paget. IX, Before my lessons began 1 was sometimes taken to the great Easter fair at Leipzig. It lasted, I believe, three weeks, and was world famous; the great mart of exchange for all countries. We used to start in the dark, for it was a twenty-mile drive, and go for breakfast to my grandmother who had a house at Leipzig. The whole picturesque old town was tilled with booths, and the narrow thorough fares seethed with a motley crowd shimmering in every colour of the rainbow'. There were Russians and Poles with their furs, Turks with carpets, Ar menians, Chinese, Arabs, Japanese, Negroes, Italians, and Greeks, all in their national costumes. The booths were piled with foreign wares; panoramas, tight-rope dancers, merry-go-rounds, and musicians took up every other available space. There were circuses for the children in the daytime and theatres for the grown-up people at night, and celebrated actors and even stars like Rachel and Dejaset came from Paris. People flocked into town from country houses to hear them, for the generation of that day still had the French tradition. Christmas is, however, for every German child the pinnacle of the year. It is not only a time full of the intensest expectation and excitement, but it is very holy and mystical. The Christkindchen sheds its halo over every child. If on Christmas Eve you look through the curtainless window's of the poorest labourer’s cottage, you will see a little Christmas- tree lit up and adorned for the children. For weeks beforehand my mother, our governesses, and any lady guests there might be, were employed in mys terious work shut up in jealously closed rooms. We children passed the long winter evenings in gilding apples and nuts, and cutting out ornaments in many-tinted papers for the Christmas-tree. Every thing was made at home, and therefore more preci ous. My mother, who was the moving spirit in all these preparations, observed absolute silence ; but she went to town for two or three days and re turned with a carriage piled with parcels. It was, I believe, on one of these expeditions that the coach man, as it got dark, lost his way in the snow. My mother, perceiving a signpost at some little distance, sent the footman to read the directions. This man, very stalwart and rather illiterate, did not succeed in doing so, and uprooting the sign-post carried it to the carriage door for my mother to read. The village people and the servants had their trees be fore we had ours, and everybody received a pre sent adapted to their wants and their wishes; not the least of them w'as forgotten. The guests, too, had each a remembrance, pretty or pseful as the case might be. I remember one year when my mo ther’s ingenuity was particularly taxed to find the right things, as the Prussian army had been mobi lised, and we, being at one of my father’s Prus sian places, had for five or six weeks over thirty officers quartered in the house. The great ball-room was made into a wood of fir-trees with one very large one in the middle. They were all covered with glittering fruit and coloured devices, and lit with hundreds of wax tapers. This was the last Christ mas in one of our beloved homes, so soon and so sadly to be broken up. As I look back it seems to me that life in those days was so simple, so ample, so dignified. There was breathing time and space, and people grasped events; whilst now they seem to slip through their fingers and their thoughts. There were no tele grams, no telephones, no electricity, no bicycles or motors—such things had never been thought of; and when an old woman in the village prophesied just before her death that carriages would run on the roads without horses, and people fly along on a wheel as fast as trains went (in those days), every body said she was mad. I hear people now talk ing of communicating with Mars. Are they so very mad as we think? My only excuse for recalling these childish, and I fear too personal, memories is that they refer to a time already so far distant that very few remember it, and a younger genera tion may be amused and astonished that once there were those who lived with so little excitement and yet were quite happy and contented. (The End.) . * From the Nineteenth Century. BRITISH|AND GERMAN PROSPERITY. ILLUMINATIVE STATISTICS. By the way, the Liberal motto is “No taxation without repre sentation,” and the axiom naturally follows, “No representation without taxation.” Why, therefore, should all incomes under £160 practically escape Imperial taxation ? That, and the following facts are respectfully commended to the attention of all professional robbers of hen roosts! “Firstly, with a population of 880,000, no less than 229,859 persons, or, practically every adult, paid income tax. Secondly, 146,000 persons paid income tax on incomes of £100 and under; but the rates are merely nominal, being on the average 5s. 7d. on incomes up to £50, and from £50 to £100 the total tax averages only 9s. Id. Thirdly, regard ing middle-class incomes, from £160 to £700, Ham burg has one in 33 of the population, against only one in 54 in the United Kingdom. Fourthly, re garding high incomes, beloved by incipient hen roost robbers, i.e., £5,000 and over, Hamburg has in its population one in 1,470, and the wealthy British I les only one in 4,200, or one-third as many! After vhir, what price the rhodomontades of Free Trade apostles regarding our superior prosperity?” SEQUEL TO THE'FRENCH EXECUTIONS. SCENE IN A MEDICAL 8CHOOL. Paris, January 14. The Journal publishes the following telegram from Lille: “The brother of Deroo, one of the men exe cuted at Bethune on Monday, succeeded in gaining :n entrance to the Medical School here yesterday, by passing in with some students, and reached the lecture room, where the head of the murderer is exposed, before he was noticed. Shaking his fist at the head, the man exclaimed, ‘Scoundrel! This is how I find you. You have brought dishonour on our whole family. The family’—he then rushed for ward to seize the head, but overcome by excitement, he staggered and fell to the floor, and had to be removed to his home.” A TAX ON BANDSMEN. With the new year a very curious law came into force in Sweden. Last October, in order to satisfy native artists who declared that they were being crowded out by foreigners, especially Germans, the Parliament passed a law by which a tax of five per cent, was levied on all foreign operatic, theatri cal, and other entertainments, and a tax of ten per cent, on the salaries of foreign artists. The Ger mans, remarks a contemporary, are very much an noyed at this law, for they supply most of the musicians who play in the Swedish restaurants, and they fear that Denmark and Norway will impose similar restrictions on them. The three Northern Kingdoms form a great outlet for the second-rate musician of Germany, and if all three put a tax on these people the Germans will have to turn their attention to other countries. full_text: THE DAILY RECORD, SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1909. No. 893. □ BERLIN Up to going to press our usual Berlin letter had not arrived, presumably owing to a delay in the post, and we therefore regret the dearth of Berlin social news in this issue. 1 According to latest reports, the King and Queen of England are expected to arrive in Berlin on Fe bruary 8th, and will make a five days’ stay at the Imperial Court. Their Majesties’ suite will include: Lord Althorpe, the Lord Chamberlain; Lord Howe, Lord Granville, Major Ponsonby, Lady Antrim, and Miss Knollys, sister of the King’s private secre tary. Sir Charles Hardinge will also accompany his Majesty as representative of the British Foreign Office. The German Ambassador in London, Count Wolff- Metternich, last Wednesday delivered to the Vice- Chancellor of Oxford University the portrait of Em peror William painted by Professor Schwarz. The portrait shows the Emperor in the robes of a Doc tor of Law, which honorary degree was conferred on his Majesty by Oxford University during the Imperial visit to England in the close of 1907. The portrait was some time ago on exhibition in Berlin at Schulte’s gallery. It will be hung in the Com memoration Hall of the University. Princess Anna zu Schaumburg-Lippe (nee Princess of Sachsen-Altenburg) has arrived in Berlin and taken up her residence at the Hotel Continental. On Tuesday next, January 19, at 7.30 p.m. a concert will be given in the Philharmonie for the benefit of the earthquake sufferers in Sicily and Calabria. This concert, which is under the patronage of the Crown Prince, was arranged by Colonel Chelius, and an honorary committee, including Coun tess Harrach, has been formed. Their Majesties the Emperor and Empress have consented to attend the concert, which is expected to prove highly success ful. Tickets are obtainable at Bote and Bock’s and Wertheim’s music stores. A particularly interesting and unique dog show is to be held in the exhibition hall of the Berlin Zoological Garden from February 20th to 23rd, in clusive. Two of the four days will be devoted to viewing and judging dogs not employed for sport ing purposes,—viz. lap-dogs, dwarf dogs, dogs trained for ambulance, war, police, and sheep duties; while the other days will be set apart for judging sport ing dogs. This arrangement is expected to be cor dially welcomed by exhibitors and spectators, as it will avoid all confusion and greatly facilitate the careful judging of the respective animals. Prospec tive exhibitors and others desirous of obtaining in formation about the exhibition should write to the office of the “Hektor-Ausstellung,” Potsdamer Strasse 125, Berlin, W. Another student of the Institut Tilly, Berlin-Gross- Lichterfelde, this time a lady, Miss Pearl Hart (A.B. of Grinnell- College) from Centreville, Iowa, passed on Friday a very successful examination for the German Diploma of the Association Phonetique Inter nationale. Prof. Vietor, of Marburg University, gave her the mark “gut bis sehr gut.” Beautlfiilfy furnished flat, 8 rooms, bath-room, kitchen, to rent for one or two years. Frau Molis, BERLIN, Karlsruher Str.29. Sir Thomas Barclay writes to Wolff’s Telegraphic Agency to say that the reports published in several German newspapers of an interview which he had with a representative of the Neue Freie Presse are quite inc'orrect, and that he desires to state positively that he disclaims all responsibility for the purport of the interview as published. For the first eleven months of last year the vo lume of emigration from the ports of Hamburg and Bremen, we read, showed a marvellous de crease as compared with the figures for the corres ponding months of 1907. Strange to say, the re turns for December show that 7,248 emigrants sail ed from Hamburg as compared with 6,494 persons in 1907, while the emigrants through Bremen were 11,968, as against 6,186 emigrants in December, 1907. But it must be remembered that almost the whole of the emigrants from the port of Bremen were Russian Jews or Polish Jews, and the great in crease for the month referred to must not be taken as representing really the tide of emigration of Ger man workers seeking new homes and work across the seas. During 1907 the emigrants from Hamburg num bered 189,810; last year they numbered only 78,878 souls, a decrease of 110,832 persons, while from Bremen there sailed in 1908 only 74,626 persons, as compared with 231,011 in 1907, or a decrease of 156,395 souls. One of the strangest marriages on record has just taken place at Boston, Mass., Capt. Conasi, of the Italian Navy, marrying Miss Jane Leland, an American heiress. The captain was in attend ance on the Duke of the Abruzzi during his me morable visit to the United States. He was intro duced to the lady at a reception. He knew no English, and she was ignorant of Italian. By chance he made a remark in Japanese. , To his astonishment the lady replied in the same lan guage. Explanations followed. He had been sta tioned at Japan. She had lived there with her fa ther for some three years. Each for love-making abandoned the natural tongue, and Japanese took the place of Esperanto, at least so says a Paris contemporary. BRITISH AND AMERICAN REPRESENTATIVES. Another shock of earthquake was felt yes terday, but the night passed quietly. The census of the survivors in Messina is now nearly completed. Rome, January 15. The Emperor William has conferred the Order of Louisa on the Queen of Italy. The Popolo Ro mano remarks: “This amicable and spontaneous de cision of the friendly and allied ruler will be re ceived by all Italians without exceptions with sin cere pleasure.” MALICIOUS RUMOUR CONTRADICTED. Copenhagen, January 15. During the Parliamentary debate on the second reading of the budget of the Ministry of War, the Minister for Defence expressed the regret with which he had seen reports of the presence of foreign war ships in Danish waters for purposes of exercise. Such reports, said the Minister, only did harm ; the enquiries which had been held had proved their utter baselessness. DEATH OF ADMIRAL ROJE8TVEN8KY. St. Petersburg, January 14. Vice-Admiral Rojestvensky died early this morning. (It will be remembered that a report of this of ficer’s death was published in the press some months ago, to be followed by a denial from the Admiral himself.) PIT DISASTER IN HUNGARY. HEAVY LOSS OF LIFE. Veszprim, January 14. An explosion of firedamp occurred yesterday in the coal-mine here in consequence of a short cir cuit. Six dead bodies have so far been found, but it is feared that there were many more miners at work in the mine at the time of the explosion. Later. During last night the fire caused by the explo sion was localised and all the exits were cleared. Out of 240 men who are now known to have entered the mine, 14 have been got out alive, and 46 dead bodies have been recovered. There are hopes of saving the rest. THE TROUBLE IN THE BALKANS. ENGLISH POLITICAL OPINION. London, January 15. Speaking on Thursday at Leicester on the Balkans question, Mr. Churchill, the President of the Board of Trade, remarked that the situation in Europe had undergone a marked improvement in the last few days, but that it was not entirely free from anxiety. The alteration of the status quo in the East had not been a sufficient cause of war. If no uncontrollable incident occurred, a peaceable solution was assured. DEATH OF A WELL KNOWN AUTHORESS. The Press Association says:—The death is an nounced, in tragic circumstances, of Mrs. Evelyn Greenleaf Sutherland, of Boston, U.S.A., who was well known in theatrical circles under the nom-de- plume of “John Rutherford” as the authoress of The Breed of the T re shams and Monsieur Beaucaire. Mrs. Sutherland had the misfortune to accidentally set fire to her clothing at an open gas stove, and although her injuries might not necessarily have proved fatal, the shock was too great for a weaken ed heart. In addition to the two plays before men tioned, Mrs. Sutherland also wrote “The Road to Yesterday,” another successful play. THE FRENCH PRESS AND ALSACE> LORRAINE. Strasburg, January 15. The prohibition of the Paris journal Matin, which has been in force for five years in Alsace-Lorraine, has now been cancelled. MOVEMENTS OF LINERS. NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD S. S. Co. Dresden office. Fr. Bremermann, Prager Strasse 49. Vice-Admiral Rojestvensky died early this morning. (It will be remembered that a report of this of ficer’s death was published in the press some months ago, to be followed by a denial from the Admiral himself.) PIT DISASTER IN HUNGARY. HEAVY LOSS OF LIFE. Veszprim, January 14. An explosion of firedamp occurred yesterday in the coal-mine here in consequence of a short cir cuit. Six dead bodies have so far been found, but it is feared that there were many more miners at work in the mine at the time of the explosion. Later. During last night the fire caused by the explo sion was localised and all the exits were cleared. Out of 240 men who are now known to have entered the mine, 14 have been got out alive, and 46 dead bodies have been recovered. There are hopes of saving the rest. THE TROUBLE IN THE BALKANS. ENGLISH POLITICAL OPINION. London, January 15. Speaking on Thursday at Leicester on the Balkans question, Mr. Churchill, the President of the Board of Trade, remarked that the situation in Europe had undergone a marked improvement in the last few days, but that it was not entirely free from anxiety. The alteration of the status quo in the East had not been a sufficient cause of war. If no uncontrollable incident occurred, a peaceable solution was assured. DEATH OF A WELL KNOWN AUTHORESS. The Press Association says:—The death is an nounced, in tragic circumstances, of Mrs. Evelyn Greenleaf Sutherland, of Boston, U.S.A., who was well known in theatrical circles under the nom-de- plume of “John Rutherford” as the authoress of The Breed of the T re shams and Monsieur Beaucaire. Mrs. Sutherland had the misfortune to accidentally set fire to her clothing at an open gas stove, and although her injuries might not necessarily have proved fatal, the shock was too great for a weaken ed heart. In addition to the two plays before men tioned, Mrs. Sutherland also wrote “The Road to Yesterday,” another successful play. THE FRENCH PRESS AND ALSACE> LORRAINE. Strasburg, January 15. The German Ambassador in London, Count Wolff- Metternich, last Wednesday delivered to the Vice- Chancellor of Oxford University the portrait of Em peror William painted by Professor Schwarz. The portrait shows the Emperor in the robes of a Doc tor of Law, which honorary degree was conferred on his Majesty by Oxford University during the Imperial visit to England in the close of 1907. The portrait was some time ago on exhibition in Berlin at Schulte’s gallery. It will be hung in the Com memoration Hall of the University. Princess Anna zu Schaumburg-Lippe (nee Princess of Sachsen-Altenburg) has arrived in Berlin and taken up her residence at the Hotel Continental. On Tuesday next, January 19, at 7.30 p.m. a concert will be given in the Philharmonie for the benefit of the earthquake sufferers in Sicily and Calabria. This concert, which is under the patronage of the Crown Prince, was arranged by Colonel Chelius, and an honorary committee, including Coun tess Harrach, has been formed. Their Majesties the Emperor and Empress have consented to attend the concert, which is expected to prove highly success ful. Tickets are obtainable at Bote and Bock’s and Wertheim’s music stores. A particularly interesting and unique dog show is to be held in the exhibition hall of the Berlin Zoological Garden from February 20th to 23rd, in clusive. Two of the four days will be devoted to viewing and judging dogs not employed for sport ing purposes,—viz. lap-dogs, dwarf dogs, dogs trained for ambulance, war, police, and sheep duties; while the other days will be set apart for judging sport ing dogs. This arrangement is expected to be cor dially welcomed by exhibitors and spectators, as it will avoid all confusion and greatly facilitate the careful judging of the respective animals. Prospec tive exhibitors and others desirous of obtaining in formation about the exhibition should write to the office of the “Hektor-Ausstellung,” Potsdamer Strasse 125, Berlin, W. Another student of the Institut Tilly, Berlin-Gross- Lichterfelde, this time a lady, Miss Pearl Hart (A.B. of Grinnell- College) from Centreville, Iowa, passed on Friday a very successful examination for the German Diploma of the Association Phonetique Inter nationale. Sir Thomas Barclay writes to Wolff’s Telegraphic Agency to say that the reports published in several German newspapers of an interview which he had with a representative of the Neue Freie Presse are quite inc'orrect, and that he desires to state positively that he disclaims all responsibility for the purport of the interview as published. For the first eleven months of last year the vo lume of emigration from the ports of Hamburg and Bremen, we read, showed a marvellous de crease as compared with the figures for the corres ponding months of 1907. Strange to say, the re turns for December show that 7,248 emigrants sail ed from Hamburg as compared with 6,494 persons in 1907, while the emigrants through Bremen were 11,968, as against 6,186 emigrants in December, 1907. But it must be remembered that almost the whole of the emigrants from the port of Bremen were Russian Jews or Polish Jews, and the great in crease for the month referred to must not be taken as representing really the tide of emigration of Ger man workers seeking new homes and work across the seas. During 1907 the emigrants from Hamburg num bered 189,810; last year they numbered only 78,878 souls, a decrease of 110,832 persons, while from Bremen there sailed in 1908 only 74,626 persons, as compared with 231,011 in 1907, or a decrease of 156,395 souls. One of the strangest marriages on record has just taken place at Boston, Mass., Capt. Conasi, of the Italian Navy, marrying Miss Jane Leland, an American heiress. The captain was in attend ance on the Duke of the Abruzzi during his me morable visit to the United States. He was intro duced to the lady at a reception. He knew no English, and she was ignorant of Italian. By chance he made a remark in Japanese. , To his astonishment the lady replied in the same lan guage. Explanations followed. He had been sta tioned at Japan. She had lived there with her fa ther for some three years. Each for love-making abandoned the natural tongue, and Japanese took the place of Esperanto, at least so says a Paris contemporary. BRITISH AND AMERICAN REPRESENTATIVES. AMERICA AM HER NEIGHBOURS. Some days ago, as our readers may recollect, we published a short article on the “American po licy" of this paper, based on a communication re ceived from one of our readers, resident in Paris. This gentleman now writes us again, to the follow ing effect:— Your very kind iway of inserting my last note to you in the Daily Record is fully appreciated, and I am sorry to have misjudged in any way the policy of your paper. It lies on my mind con stantly to work for the improvement of the re lations between other countries and my own, and I wish I had the wit to accomplish something in that direction. What a vast improvement there would be in this old world of ours if those who mould public opinion, especially editors, would unite to promote good will among the nations! “Sometime, as you* find opportunity, write up America's good faith towards Cuba; or about the remission of 18 million dollars of the Boxer in demnity fund to China; or the progress of educa tion in the Philippines; or the great temperance re form movement that lately swept over the United States; or of that wonderful moral victory ob tained over the gambling interests in New York State; or on the value of agitation as a means of bringing about national reforms." THE UNITED STATES AMD TURKEY. NAVAL TRAINING FOR TURKISH CADETS. London, January 15. The Daily Chronicle publishes a report from Washington that the United States Navy Depart ment, acceding to the request of the Turkish Go vernment, has given instructions that ten Turkish naval officers, among whom is a son of the Sultan, are to be allowed to join Admiral Sperry’s battle ship fleet in the Mediterranean for the voyage to America, in order that they may study the service routine on board American warships. INTERNATIONAL SHIPBUILDING. HUGE COMBINE PROPOSED. Newcastle, January 15. A meeting of shipowners took place here yester day. The state of maritime trade was discussed, and a resolution adopted affirming the need of form ing an international Union for mutual support. A committee was appointed, which will begin by plac ing itself in communication wjith the shipowners of the United Kingdom. THE BRITISH ARMY'IN WARTIME. DEARTH OF OFFICERS. Belfast, January 15. Mr. Lucas, the Under Secretary of the War Of fice, said in a speech delivered yesterday to a number of officers that, as a consequence of the late reorganisation of the army, 165,000 men could now be sent abroad at one time. The problem, however, was, how that army was to be kept up to its strength during a long campaign. In a great war with a civilised Power it was possible that 100,000 men and 5,000 officers would be required to maintain the regular army during the first six months. The required number of men would hap pily be available from the special reserve, but not the officers, who were even more important. PRINCE ADALBERT IN A GALE. Kiel, January 15. Prince Adalbert of Prussia, who in the early days of.this month made his first cruise in his new po sition as Commander pi a torpedo-boat destroyer, had to contend with very heavy weather in the Bal tic. UNPARALLELED ACTIVITY. (Special to the Daily Record.) It is a striking commentary on the well meant efforts of passivists the world over that international competition in naval armaments becomes more strenu ous with every passing year. A glance at the amount of fighting material launched during 1908 testifies to the truth of this assertion. No fewer than 255,750 tons of warships were launched by the great naval Powers during the past year, the respective figures being as follows: Germany (4 battleships, 1 armoured cruiser, 2 small cruisers), ‘ total 94,900 tons; Great Britain (2 battleships, one cruiser), total 45,400 tons; United States (2 battleships), total 35,800 tons; Italy (3 armoured cruisers), total 29,700; Brazil (1 battleship), 20,000 tons; Austria- Hungary (1 armoured cruiser), 14,600 tons; France (1 armoured cruiser), 14,000 tons; and Japan (1 cruiser), 1,350 tons. From these figures it will be observed that Germany launched more than double the number of ships than England in the same period, this fact being attributable to the delays experienced in connection with the German pro gramme of the preceding year, so that the sum total of warships launched by Germany in 1908 actually includes those which, under ordinary cir cumstances, should have taken the water in 1907. It should, moreover, be remembered that Germany launched no large war vessel during 1907. The above figures by no means represent the high-water mark of international naval competition. Reports from Washington announce that the Secre tary for the Navy advocates the building of four American battleships each with a displacement of 25,000 tons. These may be reduced to two, each costing over $12,500,000 (£2,500,000), but the ex ample thus set by the United States in raising the tonnage of battleships to this huge figure will as suredly be followed by other maritime Powers. The “burden of armaments" becomes a pregnant )hrase indeed when it is seen that a squadron of four modern battleships represents a sum of fifty million dollars. And the plain truth is that an international agreement to limit the dimensions of naval armaments was never less a possibility than it is today. BR1T1SH'HQRSES~F0R AUSTR1AN*ARMY. The Vienna journal Die Zeit states that General Baczak, Inspector of Remounts, is proceeding to England to buy 50 horses for stud purposes. THE NEAR EAST. SEHSATIOHAL STORIES FROM SERVIA. RUSSIA AND THE BOYCOTT MOVEMENT. Vienna, January 15. The Neue Freie Presse publishes a telegram from Semlin that there is no foundation for the rumour that King Peter of Servia would announce his ab dication at a meeting of his Ministers this after noon. Yesterday evening a Court ball was given at Belgrade; today the usual New Year’s Day ceremonies took place at the palace. Both those festive occasions passed off in the usual manner. Belgrade, January 15. There has long been great tension between the Crown Prince of Servia and the Austro-Hungarian Ambassador, Count Forgach, and it was feared that a violent scene might occur at the Court ball. Ow ing to the interference of the King and the Govern ment, the result was attained that the Crown Prince confined himself to ignoring Count Forgach, who was present with the Countess. Constantinople, January 14. The arrest of persons charged with complicity in the Fedokiaran plot continue. It is reported that the assistant of the Mutessarif of Pera has been arrested. The .newspapers state that the full details of the plot are not yet known. It appears that the Committee intended to create disturbances and to threaten the Ambassadors. One account says that the members of the Committee intended to make a demonstration during the reading of the Grand Vizier’s speech; another that they had de termined to get up an agitation on the question of the succession to the Throne. The manufacturers of St. Petersburg, Moscow, Po land, and the northern regibn of European Russia have, says a St. Petersburg report, combined and drawn up regulations, which the Russian Govern ment has just approved, with a view to taking ad vantage of the boycott of Austrian goods now being carried out so successfully in the Balkans. This union of Russian manufacturers has already orga nised in Constantinople an exhibition of patterns and samples of Russian goods; this exhibition has at tracted a great deal of attention, and the results have been very gratifying so far. It remains to be seen whether the Russian firms can follow up the success that they may now gain in the markets of the Near East. Another Russian bank is to open a branch in Constantinople; this is the Azov and Don Bank. THE SICILIAN CATASTROPHE. GERMAN HONOUR FOR ITALIAN QUEEN. Messina, January 14. Signor Casano, the Minister of War, arrived here today. He visited many of the sanitary stations and barrack huts. The wiork of erecting a provisional hospital has been commenced. A German architect employed by the German Relief Committee has ar rived here, in order to superintend the erection of huts for the necessitous survivors. Rome, January 14. General Mazza, commanding at Messina, tele graphed on Wednesday to Signor Giolitti, the Pre mier, as follows: “No survivor was found yester day, in spite of the most careful search. The En gineers are indefatigable in their work. The most urgent necessity is the erection of huts; but there is no wood, all the limited supply derived from stripping the roofs of the buildings in the neigh bourhood having been given out and used. Six plunderers have been arrested, among them three prisoners who escaped during the earthquake of De cember 28th." Rome, January 14. Fishermen say that, four or five days before the earthquake, the water in the outer basin near the Tarento lighthouse, where mussels are taken, was so hot that all marine vegetation was killed. article_text: THE SICILIAN CATASTROPHE. GERMAN HONOUR FOR ITALIAN QUEEN. Messina, January 14. Signor Casano, the Minister of War, arrived here today. He visited many of the sanitary stations and barrack huts. The wiork of erecting a provisional hospital has been commenced. A German architect employed by the German Relief Committee has ar rived here, in order to superintend the erection of huts for the necessitous survivors. Rome, January 14. General Mazza, commanding at Messina, tele graphed on Wednesday to Signor Giolitti, the Pre mier, as follows: “No survivor was found yester day, in spite of the most careful search. The En gineers are indefatigable in their work. The most urgent necessity is the erection of huts; but there is no wood, all the limited supply derived from stripping the roofs of the buildings in the neigh bourhood having been given out and used.
