English residents of Berlin will be thoroughly well repaid by a visit to the small exhibition of paintings now on view in the studio (at Hardenberg Str. 12) of M. de Swertschkoff, latterly of London, and one of Russia’s best-known animal-painters. The King of England, as lately stated in the Record, is M. de Swertschkoff’s most distinguished patron, and the choice little exhibition in the Hardenberg Strasse holds personal interest for English people in asmuch as it contains portraits of two of the King’s favourite horses, “Persimmon’’ and “Florizelli.” King Edward declared that these pictures, both of them painted at Sandringham, were the two best portraits of horses he had ever seen. So pleased was his Majesty with the artist’s work that he last year sent the one of “Persimmon” to the Royal Academy. To the lover of art for art’s sake, the chief charm of this selection of works lies, perhaps, in the fine portraits of lions, done in water-colours. Some of the smaller pictures are splendid representations of . Russian Borsoy hounds, and there is an especially good portrait of “Beetle,” a small Yorkshire terrier belonging to a lady in Berlin. A “Deutsche Dogge,” done with startling likeness to life, is also among the collection. , . The following extract from a letter written from Buckingham Palace to M. de Swertschkoff in 1908, gives some idea of the high esteem in which King Edward held the Russian painter. ...Your letter of today’s date (writes Sir Dighton Probyn) I have submitted to the King, arid 1 write now by His Majesty’s command to inform you that your excellent little picture of the great horse “Per simmon,” now, alas, dead, may most certainly be exhibited at the Academy this year. What His Majesty proposes is, to send the pic ture in his Majesty’s own name to the Royal Aca demy, later in the month, explaining that it was painted by you last summer, and that His Majesty wishes it to be exhibited at the exhibition this year. In fact His Majesty has commanded me to ar range this with Mr. Eaton at once... M. de Swertschkoff, who is as modest and retiring as he is gifted, was educated in his father’s studio. Swertschkoff Senior was the best known animal and battle painter of his time in Russia—a friend of Em peror Nicholas I. and of the present Tsar. His son, the present exhibitor, has received three times at the hand of the present Tsarina the Emperor’s prize for amateur racing {Herrenreiten) t and was for twelve years the only gentleman jockey in Russia. Mrs. Lemuel H. Murlin, the wife of the Acting- Pastor of the American Church, will be at home on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each month from 5 to 7 p.m. at Bayreuther Strasse 39. The Lyceum Club was very full on Monday evening last, when a charming “Weihnachtsfeier'' was held. Some old German Christmas music (vocal duets) open ed the evening, both soprano and alto singing one or two solos in addition. The internationalism of the Club was then brought out: Frl. Agnes Harder, a well-known writer, read ari appropriate Christmas legend of her own, in German; this was followed by a humorous French reading ; by an Italian reading, and finally by Miss Arndt’s English recitation, “The Bogies ’11 get you if you don’t watch out*” The Christmas tree, a very pretty one, was lighted up be fore the readings began. A number of pretty girls went round after the re citations with Christmas mementoes (everyone pre sent had brought a trifle) enveloped in mysterious wrappings. Frau Kommerzienrat Heyl then made an appropriate little speech, and called particular atten tion to the “Jung Goethe Fest” which is to be or ganised in a few weeks, under the kind supervision of Director Reinhardt of the Deutsches Theater. The evening* which closed with tea and chat, was a dis tinct success. Hostesses of the occasion were Mrs. Robert-Tor- now, the President of the International Board of the Lyceum Club, and Frl. Marelle. A rather unique entertainment was given by Mr. Mrs. Vernon Spencer on Christmas night, when thirty students and young friends were their first part of the evening was spent in a North Ppfe expedition, the difficulties of which were re presented by a number of original games. The rooms were arranged to resemble a winter-seene, the hostess being attired in' a “Snow Queen” costume, and at tended by three maids, of honour, Misses Clara Wind- augh,. Gertrude Mutton, and Marie Sloss. The Polar trip, though trying, was rendered bear able by the fact that refreshments had been carefully “cached,” and were reached in time. The North Pole, when attained, furnished many surprises, not the least being the fact that it consisted of pop-corn. Musical Hn. Bennett’s garten and .near Potsdamer* Platz Americas House. instruments, souvenirs, “Scherzartikel” and the like which were found en route led to the conclusion that the Pole had already been reached by some former expeditions. A “cook-stove” found among the many things unearthed supported the suggestion that it was that of Dr. Cook. There was universal dancing following the discovery of the Pole, which was continued until a late hour. Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Darlington, of Boston, who have been enjoying a month’s sojourn at the Hotel Adlon, have left for London in company with Dr. Keyes, who has been doing special work in the Ber lin clinics for some four weeks past. Dr. and Mrs. Darlington and Dr. Keyes were entertained at a fare well dinner at the Hotel Bristol on Christmas night by Dr. G. Edison Matt, of Landshuter Strasse. Mrs. Stillman Kelley had a house-party of Cali fornian friends over the holidays at Tauentzien Str. 19, including Dr. and Miss Jones, the Misses Boalt, Meyer, Angus and Palasche, and Dr. Harries. SYDNEY (N.S.W.), Thursday.-The coastal and inter-State passenger steamship service has been re duced as a result of the coal strike. The Northern coalminers, crane-employes, coal-lumpers, and trim mers have withdrawn from the Strike Congress, and have formed a separate Strike Committee. The South ern miners have adhered to the Strike Congress, and are endeavouring to arrange a settlement. MELBOURNE, Thursday.—A conference of dele gates representing the British Admiralty, the Aus tralian Federal States, New Zealand, and the Fiji Islands, which met for the discussion of wireless telegraphic communication in the Pacific Ocean, has recommended the establishment of high-power sta tions at Sydney, Doubtless Bay (New Zealand), Suva, and the Ocean Islands, with medium power stations at the New Hebrides and the Salomon Islands. All stations will be under Government control. BRITISH AND AMERICAN REPRESENTATIVES. GREAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND: Ambassador the Rt. Hon. Sir E. Goschen. G. C.V. O Embassy, 70 Wilhelm Strasse. ROME, Thursday.—The Osservutore Romano is empowered by the State Secretary of the Papal See to announce that the report published in the Parisian Petite Rejmbliqae and describing a telegram or any other message from Cardinal Merry del Val fo the Belgian Nuncio, relative to the new ruler of Belgium, the personality of his suite, or the Belgian nation in general, lacks every foundation of fact. According to a telegram from Gablonz, the recent railway smash at Uhersko, Bohemia, has had a pain ful sequel. A carpenter named Wondra, who was in the accident but escaped without injury, suddenly became insane while walking along the street on Wednesday afternoon. He imagined that his feet and hands had been severed by the wheels, and had to be conveyed to hospital. ROME, Thursday.-The Senate yesterday discussed the measures takeH to alleviate the effects of last year’s earthquake. The President recalled the terrible circumstances of the disaster in a moving speech,, and was followed by the new Premier, Signor Sonnino, who declared that he would do all in his power to make good the damage and requested Parliament to grant the necessary means to this end. After the suggested measures had been approved and adopted without debate, the House adjourned sine die. ST. PETERSBURG, Thursday.—During the last month there were 174 cases of plague, and 168 deaths from the disease in the Ural territory. CONSTANTINOPLE, Thursday.—During yester day’s session of the Chamber, several Deputies spoke on the resignation of Hilmi Pasha and declared that this step would involve the resignation of the entire Cabinet. Other Deputies represented the Grand Vi zier’s demission as a private matter. The shocking weather which prevailed in the last few days has been responsible for a number of alarm ing incidents, besides playing havoc with communica tion in all parts of the country. According to des patches from Berlin, a winter thunderstorm broke over Berlin on Wednesday afternoon when the warm wind from the south-west suddenly changed into cold and gusty squalls, intermingled with snow flurries. Such velocity was attained by the wind that a scaf fold of wood and iron erected orf the Kaiserin Augusta Allee was torn down and blown right across the street, the debris bringing with it to the ground three electric street-car standards and a tangle of wire, holding-up traffic for two hours. Near the St. Bar tholomew Chnrch a tall tree was uprooted and hurl ed to the ground. Several persons sustained slight injuries in the course of the afternoon. In Saxony the gale, mingled, with snow ancL sleet, attained typhonic velocity on Wednesday afternoon. The Munich-Dresden express had to halt between Oederan and Freiberg owing to several uprooted trees being blown across the line. A number of trees and heavy branches were hurled against the mail van and restau rant car of the express, shattering practically every window on one side. The train arrived in Dresden fifteen minutes late. VIENNA, Thursday.—The Budget provisions form ed the subject of debate in the Herrenhaus yesterday- afternoon. Herr Grabmeyr made a speech in which he touched on the peaceful solution of the annexation crisis, thanks to the loyalty of their German allies, and put forward various suggestions calculated to restore harmony in the Chamber of Deputies. He expressed his appreciation of Baron von Bienerth’s correct, national, and impartial conduct of business, and hoped that the Baron would be attended by good fortune in the future. Discussing the political situa tion, Herr Plehner said the Government’s proposal in regard to the lingual regulations of the State authorities in Bohemia and the division of districts constituted a medium course from which neither of the two contesting parties was very far removed. A State composed of several nationalities could not en dure a national policy whose final aim was racial conflict and mutual destruction (Applause) As in Austria there was no exclusively dominant race, the State itself must, represent the firm and common basis. A strong State, externally and internally, was more necessary in Austria than elsewhere. The en tire national question rested on two simple mutters: the principle of freedom Arid the principle of order;

WCompaiuf EXQUISITE PAINTING OH CHINA RICHARD WEHSENER, DRESDEN, Zinzendorf Strasse 16. MR. HALDANE ON INVASION. London, February ,26. Speaking yesterday at Brixton on national defence, the Secretary of State for War, Mr. Haldane, said the new General Staff had been hard at work and had completed the plans of coast defence. The whole coast had been divided into sections, and each section assigned to a portion of the territorial army. If an enemy came, he would find troops to oppose hun; who, if they were not strong enough in some places to prevent him from landing, would be strong enough to harass him, to keep him busy, and to check his movements. THE RADICALS AND THE NAVY. London, February 26. After a long debate, the National Liberal Federa tion has passed a resolution declaring that it can- . not at present represent to the country that the proposed increase of naval expenditure is necessary. THE MARITIME WARFARE CONGRESS. London, February 26. The final report of the Maritime Warfare Con gress, containing 71 articles, was signed today. These articles comprise a great system of generally re cognised rules of maritime warfare. “MRS. CARRIE NATION’S” LECTURE. CLEVER UNDERGRADUATE HOAX. Last Wednesday night a clever hoax was per petrated at Caius College, Cambridge. Undergra duates from all the other colleges assembled in the large lecture room to hear Mrs. Carrie Nation, who was advertised to speak on the evils of smoking and drinking. The hall was packed with lively undergraduates, smoking as hard as they could, because they were told that Mrs. Nation objected to smoking. “Mrs. Carrie Nation” addressed the meeting on various topics, but her discourse was disjointed, as the interruptions were extremely frequent. Then the audience discovered that they had been cleverly hoaxed, and that “Mrs. Carrie Nation” was no other than a prominent member of Caius College t in disguise. Some of his friends were bold enough to call him by name, but no jone on the platform moved a muscle, and the original programme was carried through. Eventually the meeting broke up amid dis order, and “Mrs. Carrie Nation” had an interview with the Dean. THE SENATE AND WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY. New York, February 26. The newspapers publish reports from Washington that the Commerce Committee of the Senate has resolved to postpone the question of the introduc tion of wireless telegraphy on ocean steamers un til next Session. £10,000 NECKLACE STOLEN AT A BALL. New York, February 26. According to a San Francisco telegram, Miss Jennie Crocker, the daughter of the well-known banker, has just been the victim of a smart pieoe of work on the part of a particufarly enterprising thief, she having lost a necklace valued at 50,000 dollars (£10,000), while attending the Mardi Gras ball last Tuesday. How the theft was accomplished Miss Crocker does not know, but up to the present all attempts to trace either the thief or the necklace failed. H. G. B. Peters Furrier 52, Prager Sir. THE AUSTRO-HUNGARIAN-TURKISH ENTENTE. THE PROTOCOL SIGNED. .Constantine?pie, February 26. The Austro-Hungarian-Turkish entente protocol has been signed. Constantinople, February 26. The Entente Protocol signed today comprises nine articles. In Article 1, Austria renounces all Jber rights in the Novibazar district. In Article 2, Tur key expressly recognises the situation created by Austria-Hungary’s decision with respect to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Article 3 declares that the Bosnians now living in Turkey and the Turks living in Bosnia retain their Ottoman nationality. Article 4 secures to Mahomedans in Bosnia the free exercise of their religion, together with the same civil and political rights as heretofore. Article 5 runs: “The Austro- Hungarian Government binds itself to pay to the Ottoman Government, within 15 days of the rati fication of the Protocol, two and a half millions of pounds Turkish in gold as an equivalent for real property owned by the Turkish State in Bosnia and the Herezgovina.” In Article 6 the Austro-Hunga rian Government binds itself, within two years after the ratification of the Protocol, to conclude a com mercial treaty with Turkey on the basis of European international law. Meanwhile Austria-Hungary con sents to the increase of the Turkish ad valorem Cus toms duties from 11 to 15 per cent., and to the ’iitroduction qf s n.ew monopolies. Article 7 prbvides that, after the ratification of the Protocol, those Austrian post-offices at present established in places where there are no other foreign post-offices, shall be closed; and that the other Austrian post-offices in Turkey shall cease to exist at the same time with those of other foreign countries. In Article 8, Aus tria-Hungary engages to support without reserve the intention of the Porte to replace the capitulations by international law. Article 9 provides that the rati fications of the Protocol shall be exchanged within two months of the date thereof. THE BOYCOTT AT AN END. Constantinople, February 26. The Grand Vizier sent telegraphic, orders today to all the provinces that boycotting must .cease, as its continuance after the signature of the entente protocol would be anti-patriotic. Triest, February 27. The Austrian Lloyds agent at Constantinople has telegraphed to the Directors here that the boycott is at an end, and that the discharge of cargoes has begun. HOCKEY AT THE SWEDISH CAPITAL. Christiania, February 26. In the hockey games today the Leipziger Sport- klub beat the Christiania Sportklub by 17 goals to 1. Prager Strasse 35 MULLER & C. W. THIEL Linen Store Saxon Damask Under-clothing. MR. TAFT ON TARIFF REVISION. New York, February 26. Mr. Taft has informed the President of the Na tional Manufacturer’s Association that he regards the revision of the Customs Tariff as the chief requisite for the improvement of the present situa tion. Mr. Taft explained later to some representatives of the Press that he wishes for a thorough revision of the existing Customs tariff, which he considers a drag on commercial business. PLOT TO MURDER PRINCE FERDINAND. Belgrade, February 26. The police have today arrested a Bulgarian and a Serb from Sofia on suspicion of intending to mur der Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria. The Bulgarian’s name is Anastasov and the Servian’s Popovitch, and their alleged design was to throw a bomb at prince Ferdinand on his arrival at Rustchuk en route from St. Petersburg to Sofia. Both the prisoners con fessed to being concerned in a grand plot formed in Sofia against the life of the Prince, and declared that they had been deputed to procure at Belgrade the requisite materials for a bomb which were to be conveyed to Rustchuk by a woman. Anastasov describes himself as a student of philosophy and correspondent of a Sofia newspaper; Popovitch says he. came to Belgrade to enrol himself as a Servian volunteer. A judicial enquiry into the case is in progress; and the police are meanwhile search ing for the woman, who, however, is not supposed to be an accomplice. NIPPED IN THE*BUD. Ratibor, February 26. The Oberschlesischer Anzeiger publishes an ac count derived from an official source of an unusual incident at the Kadrzin railway station, 'where 1 a heavy basket was left on Friday night at the parcel office, to be kept till called for, by an unknown man who at once quitted the station. As the basket was being carried to the baggage room, the men in charge of the office heard suspicious noises pro ceeding from it which induced them to remove the lid. They then discovered that the basket con tained a man; who, on further enquiry, turned out to be a workman recently released from prison. It is supposed that the intention of the two men was to rob the till of the ticket office. The identity of the man who left the basket has also been (ascertained. THE PERSIAN UNREST. Tabris; February 26. The losses on both sides in yesterday’s fighting amounted to about 100 killed and . wounded. The Khiahan quarter of the town was violently raided today by the forces of Ain ed Dauleh. Paris, February 26. The Agence Havas learns from Constantinople that the intended interview of the Persian Ambas sador with the revolutionary committee in Constan tinople has been postponed till tomorrow, in con sequence of the indisposition of the Ambassador. RENEWED EARTHQUAKES IN S. ITALY. Pal mi, February 27. At four minutes to 2 o’clock this , morning a violent undulating shock of earthquake-occurred here, and was followed at short intervals by two Others equally violent. The inhabitants were'alarmed and quitted their houses; but no loss Of life has to be deplored, though walls were thrown down in some placet. •

The Khiahan quarter of the town was violently raided today by the forces of Ain ed Dauleh. Paris, February 26. The Agence Havas learns from Constantinople that the intended interview of the Persian Ambas sador with the revolutionary committee in Constan tinople has been postponed till tomorrow, in con sequence of the indisposition of the Ambassador. RENEWED EARTHQUAKES IN S. ITALY. Pal mi, February 27. At four minutes to 2 o’clock this , morning a violent undulating shock of earthquake-occurred here, and was followed at short intervals by two Others equally violent. The inhabitants were'alarmed and quitted their houses; but no loss Of life has to be deplored, though walls were thrown down in some placet. •

Latest telegrams from the scenes of the earth quake district are as follow:—Many of the en tombed victims ; at Messina are yet believed to be. alive, and the chief efforts of rescuers are devoted to those points from whence cries for help are heard. Strong measures are being taken against plunderers and ghouls. The British cruiser “Sut lej” has arrived at Messina with the commanding admiral on board. The rest of the British squadron has left for Catania, conveying hundreds of wound ed. It has transpired that the tidal wave which devastated San Giovanni, Calabria, overwhelmed a railway train loaded with passengers, all of whom were killed. Railway communication with Reggio has been restored. Survivors of the disaster who at the moment of the shock were afloat in Messina harbour, relate that they first heard a terrible rumbl ing as of thunder, then a shrill screaming, and at the same instant an enormous wall of water raced up the harbour, overwhelming everything in its path. Rescue work at Messina has now been systematically organised, but results so far are dis couraging. In Reggio, also, the work has been at last properly organised. On Friday the cruiser “Marco Polo” arrived there wfith 100,000 rations and other necessaries. Efforts, are being made tp. convey all survivors away from the ruined centres to places of safety, as it is found that these people invariably collect in crowds and, while too unnerved to be of any use in rescue work, they considerably impede the efforts of more capable workers. The Italian Government and people are deeply impressed by the spontaneity characterising the offers of as sistance which continue to arrive in Rome from all parts of the globe-. The entire Italian press unites in expressing the profound gratitude of the nation for the tokens of humanity and friendship thus displayed. King Victor Emanuel has sent the follow ing telegram to the Premier, Signor Giolitti: “I have visited Canitollo, which is razed to the ground, and Villa San Giovanni, which has suffered equally with Messina. Rescue work has been systematically regulated in Reggio and Canitollo, but enormous difficulties are still to be overcome. It has not rained since Friday morning. The fires at Messina have for the most part been extinguished. Up to now three English and three French ships have arrived.” The King continued his inspection at Messina on Friday, and was deeply moved by the agonising scenes he witnessed. As he passed through the ruined streets the people pressed about him, stretching out their hands for aid. A child, badly injured in the head, threw itself at his feet and begged for bread and water. The King, in a voice broken by emotion, answered: “Help comes; we are all doing what in us lies to alleviate this aw ful catastrophe.” His Majesty has ordered all the warships to distribute their provisions among the starving people. Soldiers are busy night and day erecting temporary barracks out of wood, to give shelter to the victims. The Pope has given 100,000 lire to the relief fund, the Dowager-Queen Margherita 20,000 lire, and the College of Cardinals 20,000 lire towards the same object. STEPHAN, 4, Reichs Strasse Establ. 1843. succ. to Helena Wolfsohn Nachf. Leopold Elb. wires from Reggio that 2,000 dead and 3,000 in jured have been taken from the ruins. So far as can be judged, the total number of victims in Reggio is <20,'000. Twenty towns and villages of the pro vince hdve been destroyed, with loss of life approxi mating 7,000. The municipal council of Paris has unanimously authorised a grant of 30,000 francs to the earth quake relief fund. Acting on instructions from the Minister of Finance, the Bank of France has sent a preliminary amount of 100,000 francs to the Italian Government, of which sum the Bank itself contributed half. A cablegram from Washington announces that the Unifed States Government has issued instruc tions to the commander of the Atlantic Fleet to proceed with all his ships to Messina and other points which have suffered from the earthquake. It is expected that Messina will be reached the middle of this week. A London telegram informs us that the relief fufid established by the Lord Mayor had by Friday evening reached a total of £10,000. The American steamers “Julia” and “Martha Washington” have, by special request of the Duke of Aosta, been des patched from Trieste to Messina laden with pro visions, etc. Tomorrow (Monday), according to Washington advices, President Roosevelt will send a special message to Congress advocating the author isation of financial grants in aid of the sufferers from the earthquake. EARTHQUAKE AT ALGIERS. - Algiers, January 2. An earthquake was felt in several parts of the town yesterday evening. The shocks continued for three minutes, and the telephone communication was interrupted. FESTIVITIES AT CONSTANTINOPLE. THE SULTAN’S HOSPITALITY. Constantinople, January 1. Yesterday’s banquet at the Yildiz palace in honour of the Chamber made a great impression on the deputies. After the dessert, the first Yildiz Secre tary read a speech from the Sultan to the effect that it had given his Majesty much pleasure to dine with the representatives of the Ottoman na tion, and that he believed that the occasion was a happy event in the history of the Ottoman empire. “I give you the assurance,” said the Sultan in one sentence of the speech, “that I will devote my whole soul to upholding the terms of the Consti tution, which guarantees sacred justice.” M. Ach- med Riza, in returning thanks for his Majesty’s hospitality and gracious speech, said it was beyond doubt that, as the Arabs wjould attain to high civi lisation, so also the Ottoman people, united to their Ruler, would take a high place in the civilised world. M. Riza concluded by calling for three cheers for the Sultan, which were heartily given. DIE MIL! RECORD FUND FOR THE RELIEF OF SUFFERERS FROM THE EARTHQAKE IN SICILY AND CALABRIA. Oestersund, January 1. Two sons of Ml v. Printzold, the first Chamber- lain td the King of Sweden, were frozen to death yesterday during *a ski excursion in the mountains. The oold was intense, the thermometer registering nearly 40 degrees (Fahrenheit) of frost. One of the young men was an officer in the army, the other a student. They were accompanied by a guide, and had nearly reached their destination when their strength failed them. The guide hurried on to get assistance, and soon returned with some men. One of the brothers was, however, already dead, and the other died almost immediately. RECORD AEROPLANE^FLIGHT. Ze Mans, January 1. Latest telegrams from the scenes of the earth quake district are as follow:—Many of the en tombed victims ; at Messina are yet believed to be. alive, and the chief efforts of rescuers are devoted to those points from whence cries for help are heard. Strong measures are being taken against plunderers and ghouls. The British cruiser “Sut lej” has arrived at Messina with the commanding admiral on board. The rest of the British squadron has left for Catania, conveying hundreds of wound ed. It has transpired that the tidal wave which devastated San Giovanni, Calabria, overwhelmed a railway train loaded with passengers, all of whom were killed. Railway communication with Reggio has been restored. Survivors of the disaster who at the moment of the shock were afloat in Messina harbour, relate that they first heard a terrible rumbl ing as of thunder, then a shrill screaming, and at the same instant an enormous wall of water raced up the harbour, overwhelming everything in its path. Rescue work at Messina has now been systematically organised, but results so far are dis couraging. In Reggio, also, the work has been at last properly organised. On Friday the cruiser “Marco Polo” arrived there wfith 100,000 rations and other necessaries. Efforts, are being made tp. convey all survivors away from the ruined centres to places of safety, as it is found that these people invariably collect in crowds and, while too unnerved to be of any use in rescue work, they considerably impede the efforts of more capable workers. The Italian Government and people are deeply impressed by the spontaneity characterising the offers of as sistance which continue to arrive in Rome from all parts of the globe-. The entire Italian press unites in expressing the profound gratitude of the nation for the tokens of humanity and friendship thus displayed. King Victor Emanuel has sent the follow ing telegram to the Premier, Signor Giolitti: “I have visited Canitollo, which is razed to the ground, and Villa San Giovanni, which has suffered equally with Messina. Rescue work has been systematically regulated in Reggio and Canitollo, but enormous difficulties are still to be overcome. It has not rained since Friday morning. The fires at Messina have for the most part been extinguished. Up to now three English and three French ships have arrived.” The King continued his inspection at Messina on Friday, and was deeply moved by the agonising scenes he witnessed. As he passed through the ruined streets the people pressed about him, stretching out their hands for aid. A child, badly injured in the head, threw itself at his feet and begged for bread and water. The King, in a voice broken by emotion, answered: “Help comes; we are all doing what in us lies to alleviate this aw ful catastrophe.” His Majesty has ordered all the warships to distribute their provisions among the starving people. Soldiers are busy night and day erecting temporary barracks out of wood, to give shelter to the victims. The Pope has given 100,000 lire to the relief fund, the Dowager-Queen Margherita 20,000 lire, and the College of Cardinals 20,000 lire towards the same object. full_text: 2 THE DAILY RECORD, SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1909. 1 ' No. 1,157 —■e=e=s B E R CAPTAIN BELKNAP’S LECTURE. (From our Berlin Correspondent.) A caricature of himself, drawn by one of his col leagues in the American house-building at Messina, and in which the Mayor of Messina figured still more prominently, was one of the “telling” pictures thrown upon the slide on Tuesday evening to illustrate the lecture delivered by Captain Belknap at the American Church. The Mayor of Messina, in his farewell address, eulo gising the work which Captain Belknap had done for the earthquake-shaken city, had indicated that he “wished he had the voice of a siren” to persuade Cap tain Belknap, to remain longer in Messina. The ca ricature showed Captain Belknap, standing with his back towards Italy, on a vessel making seawards. Out of the water near the shore rose the stalwart and bearded figure of the Mayor of Messina, harp in hand, looking longingly after the vanishing naval attache. “O would I could charm the sirens to keep thee, illustrious Cap., in this most unhappy land,” was written beneath the cartoon, which evoked con siderable mirth from the audience in the American Church. The Mayor of Messina had used a high-flown ex pression. But it obviously reflected very sincerely the keen realisation on the part of the Italian author ities of the vast benefit which Captain Belknap and his co-workers, acting for America, had bestowed upon the stricken Italian towns. “The heart of a philan thropist, the soul of an artist/’ was another epithet conferred upon the superintendent of the American relief-work. This phrase might also make some appeal to the American sense of humour, as applied to the building of several hundreds of small and absolutely uniform wooden houses. But it likewise indicates the deeply-felt gratitude of the Italians to whose relief America came, and also forcibly suggests the tact which must have been brought to bear by those un charged with the mission, in everywhere studying, as far as was practicable, the susceptibilities of the Italians. Trees, for example, were left standing by the Americans wherever possible, amongst the groups of white-painted cottages. In Reggio the little build ings were undeniably picturesque, painted white with bright green doors and brick-red foundations. Captain Belknap spent very little time in touching upon the hardships which the work is known to have imposed upon the meii who, headed by himself, sacri ficed themselves and their personal comfort in the interests of unhappy Messina. For several months they lived in the small portable cottages built by themselves ; but while admitting that this was not exactly a life of luxury, Captain Belknap dwelt in no way upon the discomforts endured, except to re mark that the nights might sometimes have been warmer. President Roosevelt’s visit to Messina was an in teresting topic of the lecture. Captain Belknap told how the King of Italy, first putting out to visit the Ex-President in his vessel, then escorted Mr. Roose velt on shore, where the former President of the United States made a thorough inspection of the American relief-work. The enthusiasm of the Italian crowds Captain Belknap described as tremendous. As Mr. Roosevelt drove from point to point their homage amounted to a positive inconvenience. To keep ahead of the crowd was most desirable, but none-the-less difficult, and it frequently became necessary, in pass ing over the wretchedly rough ground, for the ho nourable inmates of the vehicle to dismount in order that good time could be made, out of reach of the enthusiastic Italian populace, ^s Mr. Roosevelt, at the close of his brief visit, made his way back to his boat through the midst of the people, their de light broke all bounds, and taking complete pro prietorship bf him, they cheered wildly with cries of “Our King! Our President!” A suggestive illustration which Captain Belknap showed was that of one of the American-erected buildings with a large bell slung in the trees be hind. This was one of the numerous church-bells which were to be found scattered about the ruins at Messina. The American relief-workers had obtained permission of the Church authorities to utilise this bell for calling the gangs of labourers to their work. When it had for the last time discharged this office it was again to be hung in a Church in Messina, presumably with some fitting inscription describing the novel use to which it had been put. Miss Otis, who has already established dancing classes in Dresden, has now made definite arrange ments for similar classes in Berlin. The classes will be held on Tuesdays. Esthetic (Gilbert) dancing for ladies, from 11-12 o’clock. Social dancing for boys and girls: beginners, 4.30- 5.30; for more advanced pupils, 5.30-6.30. It is desired that on the opening day all pupils in social dancing meet at 4.30. Until more satisfactory arrangements can be made the classes will be held in the Victoria Saal, Luther Strasse 31—where Miss Otis can be seen after twelve o’clock by any one desiring to make ar rangements for private lessons. Mrs. Thackara, Mrs. Hitt, Mrs. Belknap, Mrs. Shartle, Mrs. Grew, and Mrs. Scholle have kindly con sented to act as patronesses. L I N ^— — = OSTEOPATHY. = W. J. E. Dillabough, graduate formerly N.Y. (Continued.) admission to Anti-Budget meetings issued by the Budget League, so as to enable its myrmidons to create disorder. These are weapons that dirty the hands of their users.—Meanwhile, we must not forget the most important factor in the present struggle,—the with holding of supplies from all the great services. Until this or a new Budget is passed, the Exchequer is theoretically insolvent. Some 25 or 30 millions sterl ing of revenue already collected under the Budget must be refunded if the Bill is rejected. In addi tion to this sum is the deficit which existed at the commencement of the fiscal year) calculated at 15 mil lions. The total sum to be met in the event of a Budget rejection will, therefore, fall not far short of 45 Or 50 million pounds. The gravity of this cir cumstance can hardly be exaggerated, and the respon sibility which the peers are taking upon themselves by holding up the Finance Bill may be accurately guaged therefrom. That many of them are recoiling in horror from the prospect cannot be doubted after the lead given by Lord Cromer, Lord Rosebery, and Lord Balfour of Burleigh. TOKIO (Japan), Friday.—A terrible explosion has occurred in the Onura coal mine, province of Fu kuoka. So far as can be ascertained, fifteen men have lost their lives and 228 others are still entombed in the pit. SCHWERIN, Friday.—Press reports recently cir culated to the effect that the Grand Duchess Alexandra of Mecklenburg-Schwerin anticipates an interesting event in the spring of next year are now officially con firmed. MADRID, Friday.—The War Ministry announces that all is in readiness at Melilla for the resumption operations against the Riff tribesmen, which are ex pected to commence at once. BELGRADE, Friday.—The King of Bulgaria ar rived here yesterday afternoon, and was greeted at the station by King Peter, the Crown Prince, For eign Minister Milovanovitch, and other personages. After introductions among the suites of the two mon- archs had been made, they drove to the palace, not by the direct route, which was strongly guarded by military, but by a roundabout way, at every point of which the people raised hearty cheers. PEKING, Friday.—The Government has issued an edict to the officials of chief towns and provinces by which they are admonished that all measures necessary for the introduction of a constitutional regime within the stated period must be fulfilled in detail. The edict is intended to give the people an assurance that the Regent is determined upon making good all the promises given by the late Emperor Kwangsu. TEHERAN, Friday—The Persian problem has been greatly complicated by a murderous attack updn a caravan in which two Russian Consuls, MM. Passek and Kadlulovsky, were travelling. The attack was made by fifty mounted tribesmen and 200 on foot who belonged to the Kashkai tribe. The escort of the Consular caravan, which was journeying in com pany with six Persian trade caravans, were too weak to withstand the heavy fire poured into them by the marauders, who swarmed on all sides of the iengthy train, and surrender was finally made. The casu alties in the Russian caravan were very heavy, and ten people were also killed among the Persian traders. After surrender had been made the bandits pillaged the caravans of all valuables, and it was only by the greatest effort that the two Consuls, who were un injured, managed to save the archives and money- chest of the Consulate from the thieves. The Russian Minister here has made the strongest representations to the Persian Government, demanding that immediate measures be taken for the punishment of the ma rauders and stating that he will hold the Government responsible for all losses, which must be indemnified. The British Consul at Shiras, as soon as he received news of the outrage, set out for the scene of the fight attended by a doctor and a small escort of Anglo-Indian troops. MADRID, Friday.—An official telegram from Te- neriffe states that the main lava stream from the crater is advancing to the north, after having divided into two branches, one of which flowed two miles in nine hours. Streams of lava pouring down upon Santiago and Tamara have increased their volume. The flight of the populace continues. (From our correspondent.) NEW YORK, Nov. 16. —For the protection of their interests the proprietors of Hampton's Magazine, which has obtained from Commander Peary the right of publishing his North Pole story in serial form on a contract of 50,000 dollars, have insured Peary’s life for the sum of 50,000 dollars. The policy is so arranged that with the completion of each month’s article the amount is reduced by 5,000 dollars. Peary will contribute ten articles in all, so that each article is valued in the contract and in the insurance policy at 5,000 dollars. ST. PETERSBURG, Friday.—The Imperial Senate has revoked the permission granted some days ago by the courts to a woman lawyer, according to which she was admitted to the Bar. The Senate gives as its reason for revoking the sanction that the ad mission of women to the legal profession is a step of high importance, one which must be carefully re gulated by legislation ST. PETERSBURG, Friday.—With reference ,to reports in the foreign press of Russian-American ne gotiations about the expansion of the Amoor railroad and the laying of a second track to the Trans-Siberian Railroad by an American syndicate, your correspondent in this city is authorised to give a categorical denial to the reports, the denial being based on information obtained from the Ministry of Finance and the Min istry of Communications. No negotiations have takbn place, and no such proposals as those suggested have been made.

Captain Belknap told how the King of Italy, first putting out to visit the Ex-President in his vessel, then escorted Mr. Roose velt on shore, where the former President of the United States made a thorough inspection of the American relief-work. The enthusiasm of the Italian crowds Captain Belknap described as tremendous. As Mr. Roosevelt drove from point to point their homage amounted to a positive inconvenience. To keep ahead of the crowd was most desirable, but none-the-less difficult, and it frequently became necessary, in pass ing over the wretchedly rough ground, for the ho nourable inmates of the vehicle to dismount in order that good time could be made, out of reach of the enthusiastic Italian populace, ^s Mr. Roosevelt, at the close of his brief visit, made his way back to his boat through the midst of the people, their de light broke all bounds, and taking complete pro prietorship bf him, they cheered wildly with cries of “Our King! Our President!” A suggestive illustration which Captain Belknap showed was that of one of the American-erected buildings with a large bell slung in the trees be hind. This was one of the numerous church-bells which were to be found scattered about the ruins at Messina. The American relief-workers had obtained permission of the Church authorities to utilise this bell for calling the gangs of labourers to their work. When it had for the last time discharged this office it was again to be hung in a Church in Messina, presumably with some fitting inscription describing the novel use to which it had been put. Miss Otis, who has already established dancing classes in Dresden, has now made definite arrange ments for similar classes in Berlin. The classes will be held on Tuesdays. Esthetic (Gilbert) dancing for ladies, from 11-12 o’clock. Social dancing for boys and girls: beginners, 4.30- 5.30; for more advanced pupils, 5.30-6.30. It is desired that on the opening day all pupils in social dancing meet at 4.30. Until more satisfactory arrangements can be made the classes will be held in the Victoria Saal, Luther Strasse 31—where Miss Otis can be seen after twelve o’clock by any one desiring to make ar rangements for private lessons. Mrs. Thackara, Mrs. Hitt, Mrs. Belknap, Mrs. Shartle, Mrs. Grew, and Mrs. Scholle have kindly con sented to act as patronesses. L I N ^— — = OSTEOPATHY. = W. J. E. Dillabough, graduate formerly N.Y. article_text: CAPTAIN BELKNAP’S LECTURE. (From our Berlin Correspondent.) A caricature of himself, drawn by one of his col leagues in the American house-building at Messina, and in which the Mayor of Messina figured still more prominently, was one of the “telling” pictures thrown upon the slide on Tuesday evening to illustrate the lecture delivered by Captain Belknap at the American Church. The Mayor of Messina, in his farewell address, eulo gising the work which Captain Belknap had done for the earthquake-shaken city, had indicated that he “wished he had the voice of a siren” to persuade Cap tain Belknap, to remain longer in Messina. The ca ricature showed Captain Belknap, standing with his back towards Italy, on a vessel making seawards. Out of the water near the shore rose the stalwart and bearded figure of the Mayor of Messina, harp in hand, looking longingly after the vanishing naval attache. “O would I could charm the sirens to keep thee, illustrious Cap., in this most unhappy land,” was written beneath the cartoon, which evoked con siderable mirth from the audience in the American Church. The Mayor of Messina had used a high-flown ex pression. But it obviously reflected very sincerely the keen realisation on the part of the Italian author ities of the vast benefit which Captain Belknap and his co-workers, acting for America, had bestowed upon the stricken Italian towns. “The heart of a philan thropist, the soul of an artist/’ was another epithet conferred upon the superintendent of the American relief-work. This phrase might also make some appeal to the American sense of humour, as applied to the building of several hundreds of small and absolutely uniform wooden houses. But it likewise indicates the deeply-felt gratitude of the Italians to whose relief America came, and also forcibly suggests the tact which must have been brought to bear by those un charged with the mission, in everywhere studying, as far as was practicable, the susceptibilities of the Italians. Trees, for example, were left standing by the Americans wherever possible, amongst the groups of white-painted cottages. In Reggio the little build ings were undeniably picturesque, painted white with bright green doors and brick-red foundations. Captain Belknap spent very little time in touching upon the hardships which the work is known to have imposed upon the meii who, headed by himself, sacri ficed themselves and their personal comfort in the interests of unhappy Messina. For several months they lived in the small portable cottages built by themselves ; but while admitting that this was not exactly a life of luxury, Captain Belknap dwelt in no way upon the discomforts endured, except to re mark that the nights might sometimes have been warmer. President Roosevelt’s visit to Messina was an in teresting topic of the lecture. Captain Belknap told how the King of Italy, first putting out to visit the Ex-President in his vessel, then escorted Mr. Roose velt on shore, where the former President of the United States made a thorough inspection of the American relief-work. The enthusiasm of the Italian crowds Captain Belknap described as tremendous. As Mr. Roosevelt drove from point to point their homage amounted to a positive inconvenience. To keep ahead of the crowd was most desirable, but none-the-less difficult, and it frequently became necessary, in pass ing over the wretchedly rough ground, for the ho nourable inmates of the vehicle to dismount in order that good time could be made, out of reach of the enthusiastic Italian populace, ^s Mr. Roosevelt, at the close of his brief visit, made his way back to his boat through the midst of the people, their de light broke all bounds, and taking complete pro prietorship bf him, they cheered wildly with cries of “Our King! Our President!” A suggestive illustration which Captain Belknap showed was that of one of the American-erected buildings with a large bell slung in the trees be hind. This was one of the numerous church-bells which were to be found scattered about the ruins at Messina. The American relief-workers had obtained permission of the Church authorities to utilise this bell for calling the gangs of labourers to their work. When it had for the last time discharged this office it was again to be hung in a Church in Messina, presumably with some fitting inscription describing the novel use to which it had been put.

English and American newspapers. Oifico hours 9—1. 3—B, Sa.trirdn.vs 9—H. WINTER SPORT AT GEISING. (Special to the Daily Record.) The fourth annual Winter Sports Meeting was held at Geising on Saturday and Sunday last, the 23rd and 24th of January, under the auspices of (the Dresden Ski Club. Although the snow on the hills where the evnts took place was crusted and hard, the actual weather conditions were very favourable, and all the races were successfully brought off. On Saturday afternoon, the first series of the Bobsleigh-Race, and' a long-distance Military Ski Race were run. For these two events the spectators were not very numerous, as the majority came only for Sunday. In the Bobsleigh trial on Saturday, the “Marabu” (Dresden A.S.C.) made the best time, with Tavel as steerer, and Marcuard at the brake; this race had to be run on the Zinnwalder Road, as the bobsleigh run was not as yet in good condition ; the best time was 4min. for 4 kilometres. The first event on Sunday morning was another Military Ski Race, distance 6 kilometres, won by Gefreiter Viertel, of thje 12th Jager Battalion, in 44min. 45sec. The next event was the Open Ski Race, distance 4 kilometres, won by Ziesche (Tep- litz), time 23min. 53£sec. Then came the Obstacle Ski Race, on a difficult and winding track, wh(ich obliged the competitors to give proof of their effi ciency in the Christiania and Telemark-Swings, the former being used for sharp turning, and the latter for braking; this race was won by Schildbach (Gott- leuba). The last of the ski races was that open to children under 14 years of age, and was won by Fischer (Teplitz), distance 2h kilometres, time 25m£n. 1 Osec. The next three events were the Rodel Races on a run 1 kilometre in length. The first class was for gentlemen on single sleds; the winner of this race was Petzold (Geising), time 38 8 osec. The ladies’ Race was won by Frl. Krumpoldt (Dresden), in 41 sec. The third class was for double sleds, and the winning time, 36sec., was made by Knauth and Otto (Altenberg). In the Steerable Sled Race, the first and third places were won respectively by Collett and Bayer, and von Frenkell and Schou, both teams from the Dresden A.S.C., and both on Norwegian Sjeltke sleds; thie distance was 2 km., and the winning time 3min. 28sec. This was the last of the morning events. The Ski Jumping began at 2 p.m., and drew a very large crowd of spectators. The run before the take-off was between 25 and 30 metres long, and the slope about 25 degrees. This, of course, did not give any opportunity for very remarkable jumping, but very nearly the best possible jump under the circumstances was made. Six competed, only two of whom lost their balance at all out of three jumps each. As was to be expected, the best showing was made by the three Norwegians who entered the competition, and Oskar Blich (Dresden A.S.C.), champion ski-runner of Saxony, won with a jump of 15 metres, Jespersen being second with an 11 metre jump. The event was closed with an exhibition double-jump of 17 metres by Julius and Oskar Blich, who took the landing incline hand in hand, stopping at the end with an exceedingly well executed Telemark Swing. , The final event was the second series of .the Bobsleigh Race, run on the regular bob-track, two kilometres in length. The curves were sharp and the run fast,—conditions which necessitated expert steering and frequent application *of the brakes. The “Jockel” (Dresden A.S.C.) made the best time, with Wichmann steering and Jacobi at the brake; the “Marabu” was a close second. The latter, however, having made a better average time for the two series, won the first place. HUMAN FLOTSAM. The Captain advises those who wish to study the lowest dregs of the earth, to give the slums of London a rest, and watch the throngs who besiege the office of the agents who undertake to supply the cattle boats with “help” at Montreal. German and Russian Jews, Dukhiobors, Italians, negroes; broken-down “sharks” and “confidence men” from the large cities of the United* States ; one-time money ed youths from the larger English towns, who in a single month (or less) in New York, Montreal, or Toronto have run through the capital given them to start up in business, and are returning on the off-chance of getting more. All bustling and hustling each other after the same prize—a free passage to London, the home, and often the grave, of the desperate. —i— “FEAR AND SAVOY NEVER MEET.” King Victor Emmanuel’s happiness is distinctly of the domestic type. But although he is quiet, fond of his wife and children, and decidedly com monplace in his tastes, personal bravery is wonder fully marked in his character, and whenever danger has overtaken his people—such as the earthquake that has shocked the entire world recently—he has been the first to arrive on the scene of devastation or illness The motto of his great house is firmly graven on his heart, and over and over again he has shown that “Fear and Savoy never meet.” CHURCH SERVICES: DRESDEN. full_text: No. 898. THE DAILY RECORD. FRIDAY, JANUARY 22, 1909. □I DRESDEN The ice-festival on the Carola See, which was ori ginally to have taken place on the 9th of January but vyas postponed in consequence of weather condi tions, is announced for tomorrow (Saturday), from 1.30 to 6 p.m. The festival has been arranged by the Dresden Johannes-Verein, under the patronage of H.R.H. Princess Johann Georg, and the charitable work of this organisation among needy women and children is too well known to call for further com mendation. Apart from its benevolent and deserving object, however, the Festival will present sufficient attractiveness of its own to warrant a record at tendance. Royalty has promised to attend the event, and for the occasion the Carola See, always a po pular skating resort, will be brilliantly decorated and illuminated. A concert will be held during the en tire afternoon, and other attractive features will be: figure-skating, a costume quadrille, children’s amuse ments, a Chinese lantern procession, and a ladies’ hat competition. The three ladies whose hats receive the largest number of votes will be awarded a mark of distinction. Refreshments will be provided in the adjacent restaurant, in addition to which buffets will, be erected on the rink, presided over by ladies and gentlemen of the Committee. The remarkably reasonable prices of admission are another feature, viz. one mark for adults and 50 pfg. for children! For a highly enjoyable way of spending tomorrow afternoon we can recommend this Festival to our readers. Further particulars appear in the adver tisement on page four. The Baden-Baden Church Magazine for January contains a reproduction of the address presented to the Rev. T. Archibald S. White, M.A., bv his con gregation last year, on the conclusion of forty years’ Ministry, thirty-seven of which have been passed at Baden. It speaks in appreciative terms of the unceasing endeavours on the part of the popular chaplain to beautify the church and generally add to its prosperity. We also learn from the magazine that Her Royal Highness the Grand Duchess Louise of Baden graciously presented the Chaplain with a framed portrait of H.R.H. the late Grand Duke Frederick of Baden, and that H.R.H. the Grand Duke of Baden conferred the insigna of the Order of the Lion of Zaehringen (First Class) upon the Rev. Mr. White. J The fourth Symphony Concert, series B, will not take place on Friday, the 29th instant, but on Mon day, February 1.—The cast of Richard Strauss’ music- drama “Salome,” on Tuesday, the 26th instant, will be as follows. Herodes, Herr Sembach (for the first time); Herodias, Frl. Eibenschiitz; Salome, Frau Aino Ackte, from Paris; Jochanaan, Herr Perron ; Narraboth, Herr Soot; Herodias' page, Frau Bender- Schafer; Jews, Herren Rudiger, Wolf I., Grosch, Erl, Rains; Nazarenes, Herren Hummel and Biissel; Soldiers, Herren Nebuschka and Puttlitz; Cappado- cian, Herr Wachter ; Herodes’ page, Frl. Keldorfer. Elena Gerhardt and Professor Arthur Nikisch gave their last concert of this season at the Vereinshaus on Wednesday. They must be named togethejr, be cause I have never found two artist-natures which were so fully complementary to each other as are these two; and because the endless charm that pro ceeds from one of them is reflected in the other, stimulating and intensify/(ng hfs or her art. Both parties thus gain. Elena Gerhardt never sings more beautifully than when she is accompanied by Pro fessor Nikisch; the latter never plays more impres sively than when her singing inspires him. And so it is natural that a concert given by these two gifted artists should by degrees come to be reckoned a great day in Dresden. It is so in fact, as such refined and luminous art as they exhibit compen sates for much of an inferior kind that a long con cert season produces.—Elena Gerhardt was not at her best on Wednesday, as she had hardly recovered from a severe cold; but hell mastery in things tech nical enabled her to veil her indisposition. Only at the beginning wasl a slight hoarseness noticeable; and in Wagner’s melancholy song “Im Treibhause” —which has historical interest as having been one of the composer’s studies for “Tristan und Isolde”— she was unable quite successfully to manage the subtle high notes required. The deepest impres sions were made by the singer with the “Sapphische Ode” of Brahtns and by Reger’s wonderful song, “Des Kindes Gebet.” The crowded hall rang with applause, and the audiencb slowly dispersed after listening to several extra numbers. To begin with the Far East, the Irma Company from Bur- mah, never yet seen in Europe, will celebrate their mystic rites under the leadership of their chief Big wig, before the “Jungbrunnen” in a monumental temple-court. Round about the image of the goddess quiet alcoves will invite retirement from the noipe of the revels without and afford rest and refresh ment to exhausted devotees. For the Pitti-Pooti Geisha Troupe from Japan, a genuine Japanese tea house with mats will be erected opposite the “Jung brunnen,” and here, in addition to Geisha dances, will be seen break-neck performances by Japanese acrobats. From the platform of the tea-house his Royal Highness Prince Johann Georg will receive the homage of the festive processionists. His Ma jesty King Friedrich August intends to visit the “Festwiese” after the performance of “Egmont.” The Nigger Company, Limited, is to have the ho nour of producing before his Majesty their original native dances, in which the taming of wild natures by the power of music will be demonstrated. For the troupe, which travels with its own riding ele phant and native orchestra—30 persons, including the elephant—a negro village will be built, with a bar for the sale of double-alcoholic date-juice (D.R.G.M.). Hard by the negro village the Balkan folk, in their gipsy tents, will tap the native “Slivovi)tz.” (This company, on its business card, warrants it self “chemisch frisch gereinigt.”). Between the Bal kans and Africa the cavaliers and dames of Europe will be tempted to indulge in equestrian exercise and feats in the “Concours Hippique” of a merry- go-round that goes straight (on a new system), in competition with whjch the “Tombola” w^ll turn its Wheel of Fortune. Opposite the Tombola' temple a “Concess. Priv. Standesamt” will, for a moderate fee, unite (or separate, according to agreement) couples for the term of the “Fest.” (The “Standes- amt” is provided with an urgency exit, in case of need.). In the village inn (“The Landlady of the Limes”) the rousing Opera Troupe “Salome” will produce their newest hit: “Elektra at its first per formance.” This will be wound up several times. The entirely new scenery and fitting-up is impreg nated against Feuersnot with “symphonia domes- tica.” The supply of self-baked Strauss cakes will suffice for a whole week. (A Mozart Cycle may be looked for!) The. Seven Swabians have set up a “Stammtisch” in the garden of the country inn; the Italians hold themselves apart in their own “Osteria,” a charmingly picturesque building (of thoroughly safe construction). The “Dresdner Ball-Salon” will afford the highest degree of comfort; an “Aunt Sally” in which for a very moderate payment all comers may have a shy at the greatest of Dresden’s cocoa-nuts—“Guild” and Society members pay the same price—will wage fierce competition w,ith a shooting-booth where paintings, works of art created specially for the “Fest,” may be shot at. (An ap plication to the Reichstagsdirektion for the use of the removed Jank frescoes failed because of the inordinate demands of that authority). The Rat catcher of Hamelin, with his following of children, will lead to exciting scenes; inasmuch as the “chil dren of Wilhelm Busch,” and Struwelpeter and Com pany, have announced their intention of being there. A toboggan slide, which leads directly into a bog; a dance of moorhens and Will-o’-the Wisps in the Rats- keller, to the music of the “Versunkene Glocke” ; and other joys too numerous to mention here are on the programme. Tickets, as long as the supply lasts, may be ob tained on application at the places already announced, where subscription lists are kept. The Minister of the Interior yesterday evening received a telegram announcing that Phokia, on the island of Astropalia, has been visited by a violent earthquake, which wrecked 679 houses, and that help is urgently needed. The Ministry immediately despatched £200. Eight workmen in the salt mines of the “Dette Publique” met their death. Further details are lacking. full_text: 2 THE DAILY RECORD, FRIDAY, JANUARY 22, 1909. No. 898. □ BERLIN This is par excellence a week of Court festivities, and Unter den Linden is unusually gay with gorgeous State- carriages supported by be-silvered footmen. The fanfare of royal automobiles rushing to or from the Schloss is becoming almost fatiguingly common. On Tuesday afternoon the Crown Prince and the Crown Princess received in audience the newly ap pointed Ambassador for Great Britain and Lady Goschen. Shortly before this audience the Crown Princess had received the American Ambassador and Mrs. Hill. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Orr, who to the regret of many Berlin friends were lately transferred from the American Embassy in Berlin to London, will arrive at the end of this week for a few days’ visit to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Grew. Mr. Grew is Second Secretary at the American Embassy in Berlin. Brilliant illuminations by Bengal lijghts are to beautify Unter den Linden on the evening of Ja nuary 27, the fiftieth anniversary of the Kaiser’s birthday. The illuminations wjill probably commence at eight o’clock and last an hour. The Royal School of Art Needlework has for warded a splendid collection of exhibits to the Bri tish Section of the Lyceum Club “People’s Art Ex hibition.” Interesting old country smocks and sun- bonnets, patch-work quilts, portieres, etc., are in cluded, also a beautiful curtain worth 2,000 marks. All are for sale. A collection of Irish lace has also arrived, just too late, unfortunately, to be exa mined by the Empress, whose great love of beauti ful needlework would have rendered it of especial interest to her. The Kaiserin, by the way, said many admiring things about the North Bucks lace exhibit in the English Section, and jjn the Winder- mere weaving exhibit of Miss A. Garnett, who has all her silks dyed in the colours of flowers and shrubs and in sunset shades. Already at 10.30 a.m. on Wednesday, the first day on which it was thrown open to the public, the saleswomen at the Exhibition began to find them selves in requisition. Little groups of buyers, con tinually increasing in number, moved from sedjibn to section and from booth to booth in search of foreign curiosities, artistic and useful. Throughout the next month people will be able to buy here in Berlin all sorts of articles which they must other wise rummage in all the odd corners of Europe to find. Mr. A. F. P. Hayman and Mr. J. A. Ford have been appointed Trustees of the St. George’s Church Endowment Fund, in the place of Mr. Bashford and Mr. Bynnes, lately deceased. Mrs. Hessenberg, Kurfiirsten Strasse 128, enter tained on Monday afternoon at a small tea for M. Kriebitz German lessons. Highly recommended by English , teachers in Berlin. At home 3—4 Wilmersdorf. Wilhelmsaue 118. young people in honour of Miss Gladys Holling- worth, who was in Berlin for a few days passing through with her father, one of the Directors of the Paris Westinghouse Company. Miss Eda Heinemann gave a short dramatic pro gramme at the home of Mrs. A. M. Thackara on Tuesday evening, and invited a number of her friends. Miss Heinemann was attractively dressed in Japanese costume, the^ impromptu stage being also appropri ately decorated. “Mrs. Dot,” Somerset Maugham’s popular comedy, was reproduced in German at the Schauspielhaus on Tuesday night, and continues to win the approba tion of Berlin playgoers. It is confidently expected that it will have a lengthy run. Berliners find the English comedy very similar to a German “Lust- spielschwank,” and assert that its name is the most foreign thing about it. . Frl. von Mayburg is said to give a splendid pre sentation of Mrs. Dot, the rich widow of a brewer, who is in love with the too-correct Gerald Halstane, who in turn is in love with Mrs. Dot. Mr. Halstane, however, has quite by mistake become engaged to a' pretty unsophisticated girl, to whom he considers himself bound. The three acts of the play depict Mrs. Dot's (finally successful) endeavours to instil common-sense into Mr. Halstane and cause him to break his engagement with the “junges Ganschen,” to use the German critic’s term, and marry Mrs. Dot herself. Another English play presented in Berlin the other day is one of a very different type, whose name alone breathes melodrama in its most thrilling form. “Das Madchen auf Irrwegen” (“The Girl that Wreck ed his Home”) is one of Walter Melville’s well- known sensational dramas, which apparently take well with a certain section of the Berlin public. “The Girl that Wrecked,” etc., is considerably less blood-curdling than some of Melville’s melodrama that have been staged at the Luisen Theater. There is, indeed, only one murder, and the sensational ele ment is fairly well toned down, some scenes containing a certain amount of charm and humour. The young German translator and manager, Siegfried Lutz, was called before the curtain several times, and was presented with two fine wreaths, one of them in scribed “From the British Dramatic Association, to their Esteemed Champion in Germany.” Miss Cecilia Greenwood, of Princeton, 111., S is a guest at Pension Belmont, Victoria Louisen Platz 10, where her mother and sister are also staying. Miss Greenwood was a member of Dr. Babcock’s party to Russia. Mr. and Mrs. E. G. Wyckoff, of Ithaca, who are staying at Pension von Heuckelum, also took part in the Russian study trip. There were two shocks early this morning, the second a very sharp one that lasted ten seconds. The weather is cold, with continuous Fain. A good supply of wood has now arrived, and the erection of huts is being pushed on rapidly. The fire among the ruins in the harbour quarter of the town still rages. Berlin, January 20. The Relief Committee for the benefit of the suf ferers £y the earthquake in South Italy, which is under the patronage of the German Empress, an nounces the receipt by the Central Committee of the Red Cross Society of the first report from Dr. Colmers, the chief medical officer of the field hospital which has been established for a week past at Syracuse. The report states that the hospital al ready accommodates about 60 patients, and that more have applied for admission. The cases are almost all very serious and complicated; such as burns, erysipelas, lock-jaw, etc., and the work of all con cerned in the treatment of them is therefore very hard. At Syracuse an emigrant ship is at anchor with 800 refugees on board, and there also there is great need of clothing and linen. The deputation, the report continues, has been received in a most friend ly spirit, and their efforts have fallen on grateful ground. Urgent requests for further help have been received from Naples and Catania. The Naples de pot telegraphs for clothing and linen for small fi gures, and for hut equipments. There is need also of hospital apparatus and sanitary materials. Con sul Jacob, at Catania, begs for clothing, linen, and money. Prince and Princess Bulow had subscribed 1,000 marks to the Fund. Subscriptions are earnest ly requested. The offices are at Alsen Strasse 10. POLITICAL RIOTS IN PARIS. Paris, January 21. A fracas occurred again yesterday afternoon among the students in the courtyard of the Sorbonne, with reference to the lectures of Professor Thalamas. Several of the combatants—among them the Royalist journalist Maurice Pujo, and the Bonapartist jour nalist Guy de Cassagnac—were arrested. The Re publican students then organised a demonstration in favour of their Professors. VENEZUELA AND EUROPE. THE MOTIVES OF CASTRO’S POLICY. The Hague, January 21. Senor Paul, the Venezuelan Envoy Extraordinary, has stated to a representative of Reuter’s Agency that the fall of ex-Kresident Castrof was brought about by the people. Venezuela’s dispute with the outer world was represented to be of a dangerous nature by the ex-President, as he wished to avert revolution against his own adminifstratijon. Senor Paul added that it was his hope this week to for mulate and sign a protocol re-establishing official relations between Venezuela and the Netherlands. This done, it is his intention to visl Great Bri tain, Germany, and Italy, for the purpose of per forming similar work with regard to these countries. In conclusion, the Envoy remarked that outstand ing questions between his own land and the United States would be settled in an amicable spirit, so far as that was possible. THE SERVIAN GOVERNMENT. NO NEW MINISTRY FORMED. Belgrade, January 21. It is officially reported that the Premier tendered the resignation of the Ministry on the 15th instant coupled with the expressed wish that a new' Mi nistry should be formed that would enjoy more decided support from Parliament. The King ac cepted the resignations conditionally, and at the same time gave bis consent to the opening of negotiations for the formation of a new Cabinet. These nego tiations having now proved unsuccessful, the King informed the Premier this morning that he could not accept the resignations of the Ministry, and assured him of his continued confidence. THE DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI. SENSATIONAL RUMOURS DENIED. Rome, January 21. The semi-official Giornale d' Italia deals with the rumours circulated in the foreign press as to the pending resignation of the Duke of the Abruzzi from the Italian Navy and his intention to renounce his rank as a.member of the Royal Family in order to become a private citizen. The journal characterises these rumours as fantastic inventions, and also con tradicts the reports of differences between the Duke and jiis brother, the Duke d’ Aosta. The fact is, according to this journal, that the Duke of the Abruzzi is about to undertake a tour of exploration in the Himalayas, and that his projected visit to London is in connection with this project. THE TURKISH BOYCOTT MOVEMENT. Constantinople, January 20. The Minister of the Interior has stated that he received the members of the Boycott Committee to day and recommended them to put an end to the boycott on Austrian goods. The same advice was given by the Grand Vizier, who also received the Committee. The members of the Committee replied that they were ready to follow the Ministers’ ad vice. The boycott of Bulgarian goods continues. TRAGIC DEATH IN A BALLROOM. Carlsruhe, January 21. The Governor of the castle, Offensandt von Berck- holtz, last night met his death under particularly tragic circumstances. While a Court ball was in progress the unfortunate officer had a stroke, and died immediately.

full_text: 2 THE DAILY RECORD, FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1909. No. 910. BERLIN It is interesting to note that until King Edward arrives next Tuesday, no English king will have been in x Berlin since 1723,—a period of 185 years. The last visit was paid by King George the First, who arrived in Berlin on October 8, 1723, to ne gotiate with his son-in-law, King Friedrich Wilhelm the First, with regard to a double marriage between members of their respective families. Considerable disgust has been felt among Ber liners at the moist weather—rain and thaw—which has had the upper hand in Berlin during the past few days. With the approaching visit of the King and Queen so close at hand, wet weather becomes a serious obstacle to progress in decorating the city. Flag masts, festoon posts, tribunes, etc., can if ne cessary be erected during an incessant downfall of rain; but the millions of paper roses which, at the Emperor's wish, are to make Berlin blossom into sudden spring in honour of King Edward, will look somewhat dejected if they encounter anything like the weather of the past few days. The fact that these garland decorations are to extend over such a long tract of thoroughfare will make it ne cessary to commence betimes with their adjustment. Hence the strong desire on the part of the Berlin authorities for a continued spell of dry weather prior to the visit of the King. The Royal visit to Berlin’s city hall (“das Rote Haus”) is now definitely fixed to take place on Wednesday, February 10, at 12 noon. The visit will probably last three quarters of an hour. At 1 o’clock on Wednesday the King will take lunch at the British Embassy. Tribunes for a favourable view of the entry of the King and Queen are being erected by the em ployes of the Royal Theatres outside the “Prinzessin- nen-Palais.” Tickets may be obtained from the Por- tier of the Royal Schauspielhaus. The Crown Prince himself was steering, and was slightly in jured in the face, THE UNREST IN BOHEMIA. Vienna, February 3. At today’s sitting of the Lower House, Freiherr Dr. Bienerth, the Austrian Premier, spoke as fol lows: “We have reached a serious crisis. A de cision must be come to, whether the national dis cord in Bohemia, which weighs like a nightmare on the country, throwing not only the political ma chinery but trade and commerce and all civil work out of order, shall drag on like a chronic disease, pr be so far mastered that undisturbed government and a permanent and profitable co-operation of the parties in Parliament with the Government shall be rendered possible. In the conviction that only a law can produce peace, that the clearness and explicitness of law must take the place of ambiguous regulations and arbitrary interpretations, the Go vernment appeals to the Legislature as an Absolute arbitrator, while endeavouring to limit the subjects ■of dispute by selecting the most urgent and ma ture. .... There are no longer any irreconcilable dif ferences; the only thing needed, in order to attain the desired object, is the disposition for peace. The proposals of the Government embrace, so to speak, the whole balance of the contests which have been carried on hitherto; they are based on the results of the attempts which have been made to bring the national parties nearer together The settle ment to which a way is opened by the law will at all events be better than the unsettlement which has prevailed till ,now.” THE EARTHQUAKE DISASTER. A festival in aid of the sufferers by the earth quake in Sicily and Calabria was given at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here, under the patronage of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, Baron Mayor des Planches, the Italian Ambassador, Archbishop Far ley, and others. full_text: No. 910. THE DAILY RECORD, FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1909. Ell We are requested by the Committee of the Royal Academy to state that the report published by a Dresden contemporary of the amount cleared at the Gauklerfest, is absolutely erroneous, and most like ly emanated from some totally unauthenticated and probably malicious source. The actual amount is at the most perhaps half the sum stated in that report, and would then cover the trouble and loss of time incurred by the members of the Academy in arranging and decorating the hall. As a matter of fact the students themselves not only do all the preparatory work, which takes months, but are also their own carpenters and upholsterers in pre paring the Ausstellungs-Palast for their Fete. This year all instruction in the Academy was suspended for a week, in order to enable the students to de vote all their time and energy to the work of de corating the halls. It is only by such devotion to their task that the students can gain their object of clearing a sum of money for the purpose of maintaining the Mensa Academica, and of adding to a capital fund the interest of which is in future to relieve the students of their strenuous task of providing sufficient money to cover current expenses. At present it is not possible to gain any accurate idea as to the actual sum cleared, as not all the bills have been rendered. We regret that, by a printer’s error, the date of Mr. Percy Sherwood’s coming concert was given in our number of yesterday as the 25th instant. The concert will take place at the Palmengarten on Fri day, the 26th instant, and the programme will com prise exclusively compositions by the concert-giver, in the performance of which he will be assisted by Herren Petri, Wille, and Spitzner. Next Sunday, at 5 p.m., Frl. Helga Petri will appear for the first time before the Dresden pub lic in a charity concert at the “Reformierte Kirche.” Assisted by her father, Prof. Petri, she will sing arias for soprano to the violin accompaniment by J. S. Bach. Prof. Petri will also play the Largo from the suite by Max Reger, and Herr Alfred Sittard render on the organ the Preludes and Fugues in B-minor and D-flat by Bach, as well as Reger’s D-minor “Tricate.” The sudden change of weather has put a damper upon the pursuit of winter sports, much to the dis gust of the many local enthusiasts. It has now been raining more or less incessantly since Wednes day morning, and at this rate the last traces of snow will soon disappear. Besides disappointing pleasure seekers, this sudden thaw is the cause of serious loss to all such who depend upon cold weather for their living. The late director of the Sachsische Maschinenfab- rik, Chemnitz, who had been arrested at Ismailia, Egypt, on the charge of forgery, has, according to a report of the Chemnitz Allgemeine Zeitung eluded his warders at Genoa on his way back to Germany. j An order issued by the Imperial Chancellor and published in the Reichsgesetzblatt of the 9th of January, 1909, is of special interest and importance DRESDEN I (pupil Mrs. Helen Best, London) Specialist for Treatments of the Face, Neck and for Superfluous Hair.—Manicure.— Racknitz Strasse 14, p. The said order declares that the protection of patterns for use, of patterns, and of models, provided by the Imperial law of the 18th of March, 1904, shall apply also to the International Photographic Exhibition of Dresden, 1909. That law prescribes that inventions, patterns for use, patterns, and models shown at a home or foreign Exhibition, and trade-marks dis played on goods so exhibited, shall enjoy temporary protection, with the effect that the exhibition, or other use or later publication of the* invention, pat tern, or trade-mark, shall not bar the obtainment of a legal patent or protection of a pattern or trade mark, provided that the application for such patent or protection is made by the exhibitor or his lawful successor within six months from the date of the opening of the Exhibition. These provisions are most important to ex hibitors who intend to show inventions that have not been previously made public but wish to be protected against unwarranted imitations.
